On behalf of the Australian people, I ask the minister: will he assure the Senate that interest rates will not rise by four percentage points in the next six months and that there will not be another recession before the government introduces its l-a-w tax cuts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is only one bust waiting to happen at the moment and that is right in the opposition party room. I can understand Senator Hill being a little discombobulated at the moment when his leader is on a 20 per cent satisfaction rating in one poll with a 69 per cent—soixante-neuf—dissatisfaction rating. I can understand Senator Hill being very disconcerted indeed. —I rise on a point of order, Mr President. The important issue facing this country at the moment is the government's economic policy. We went through the 1990s bust, we are now told that we are in a boom and we are about to go into the next downturn. The question relates to the government's deliberate policy of forcing up interest rates, which will only hasten that inevitability. I ask you, Mr President, on the question of relevance to ask the minister to answer the question that has been put to him rather than develop his own discursion.
—It is a little early to talk about relevance, but I would ask the minister to get on with answering the question and cease criticising the opposition exclusively.

—Well, that was a rather feeble little wind-up to the point of order from Senator Hill, and I can understand his depression. I would be feeling pretty depressed if I were him at the moment. Of course it is the case that official interest rates will continue to be adjusted as appropriate to reduce the risk of the economy overheating 12 to 18 months out.

PARA.TAB: We have made it clear that we do understand the necessity, as any responsible government would, to take into account overall economic conditions and ensure that overheating of the economy does not occur. But the kind of approach that we have adopted, the kind of approach that we have already set in train, with the interest rate rises that have occurred so far, means that interest rates will not need to rise to the same extent as they have in past cycles. It is the case at the moment that interest rates are still relatively low. The official cash rate—

TALK.START.PARA: —What! What about real interest rates?

—Senator Alston can squawk his silly budgerigar head off, but it will not make any difference to the truth of the matter, which is as follows: the official cash rate and the three-month bill rates are substantially lower than their average levels over the past 20 years. That is the truth of the matter.

PARA.TAB: It is the case that both fiscal and monetary policy will need to be carefully kept under control. But the condition of the Australian economy at the moment is not an occasion for the kind of bearish, mauling attitude that has been taken by the opposition. It is an occasion to appreciate the scale of the recovery and the implications of that growth for those Australians who have been out of work and who badly want to get into work. It is a matter of appreciating that what we have at the moment is something that we wanted and that the opposition has been yelling and screaming that it wanted for months gone by.

It is only a few months ago that I can remember Mr Downer saying—a little after budget night, on 11 May—that the budget was based on enormously optimistic, quite unrealistic growth forecasts. On budget night, he said that the economic forecasts used in the budget, most notably the predictions of growth and investment, were simply heroic leaps of faith. This was a few months ago. Mr Costello said of investment:

ANSWER.PARA: The budget's investment figures are crucial to the whole budget. If they don't come from the budget, the budget falls apart, the budget's in deep trouble.

There were doomsaying predictions that the government could not possibly meet its growth or investment targets. Both the growth and investment targets have been dramatically exceeded within a matter of months.

PARA.TAB: Is there any grace or willingness to acknowledge the significance of this growth, this almost zero inflation growth, inflation of less than two per cent? Is there any willingness to acknowledge the significance of this for the recovery of the Australian economy and for the jobs that people want? No, there is just doomsaying and naysaying from those opposite and the immediate attempt inevitably to tear down the achievement and make lousy, rotten, squalid political capital of it in order to take people's minds off their own desperate difficulties. They do not persuade anybody; they certainly do not persuade me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister and presumably his government are totally out of touch with the reality in the Australian community. We do not want this boom to lead to another bust.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction.
—I'll bet it is not your question.

—Oh, be quiet. I refer to an article in the Australian Financial Review of this day headed `Signs of strain'—and those opposite have shown signs of strain, that is for sure—`in a $40 billion industry.' As the minister would be aware, that article refers to the franchising industry and in particular to the findings of a survey conducted by the ABS for the Department of Industry, Science and Technology. Can the minister provide further information on the findings of that survey?

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to see that members of the opposition as well as Senator Burns are very interested in the franchising industry. I think senators opposite would be unaware of the fact that the franchising industry, as shown by this recent survey conducted by the ABS for my department, had an annual turnover in 1993-94 of $43 billion, employs 280,000 Australians, excluding the franchisees, and is obviously one of the major industries in Australia.

PARA.TAB: The industry is growing at a rate of between 14 per cent and 17 per cent per annum, and since 1991 has grown by over 70 per cent. The survey showed that of 832 businesses thought to be franchising 555 were in a franchise arrangement. Seven out of eight franchises have been developed in Australia, and close to 20 per cent of these—which is a very commendable figure—are now into exports in the services area. People recognise from the leaked report that the export of Australian services offers the greatest potential of all, and franchising is no exception.

The disappointing figure in the survey showed that one in six of those surveyed was in litigation between franchisee and franchisor. It is disappointing to see such a high level of disputation. It equates with a lot of anecdotal information that I have been receiving as minister over the last 18 months about the level of disputation in the franchising industry. As a result, some months ago I established an independent review of the franchising code, which at the moment is a voluntary code. That was conducted by Mr Gardini. The report is now with the government and I expect to be able to release that early in the new year.

One of the issues that those in the franchising industry, particularly franchisees, have been raising is the need for a firmer regulatory arrangement to ensure that both sides of the industry—franchisors and franchisees—are protected when they sign contracts. This particularly goes to the issue of adequate disclosure of what is in the contract with the franchisor.

This is an issue that Mr Gardini has dealt with in response to many submissions. The ABS review confirms the anecdotal information that the level of disputation and litigation is much too high, which adds extra costs to this industry which I am sure all would wish could be avoided. The government recognises that this industry offers great opportunities for people to enter small business—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. Senator Burns asked this question; he should be required to listen to the answer.
—There is no point of order.

—As I was saying, the government recognises the importance of this industry. It is one area where many people are now able to enter into a small business career in a structured way with a level of success often higher than if they went out on their own.

PARA.TAB: All the indications show that, over the rest of this decade, the growth rate in franchising will be above the average of small business growth. Therefore, it is a very important industry, and we recognise it. We want to commend those in the Australian franchising industry who, over the years, have shown commendable attention by putting structures into place to ensure that their industry grows rapidly to the benefit of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Prior to the 1993 election, the Prime Minister said, `What I am promising is not to put up taxes.' In December last year, the then Treasurer said, `The government has no plans to raise taxes.' Do the minister and the Prime Minister stand by these solemn promises? If not, why should the Australian public not conclude that the Prime Minister is a compulsive and pathological liar who is prepared to cheat and commit electoral fraud in order to save his own political scalp?

—When it comes to cheats and pathological liars, it ought to be understood that that was a very incomplete quote that we had from Senator Alston on that occasion, and it was a deliberately misleading quote. If I were ruder, I would say it was a pathologically dishonest quote.

PARA.TAB: What the Prime Minister said was this: the government remains committed to not increasing the overall burden of taxation `to maintain the tax to GDP ratios we roughly have at the moment. In other words, what I am promising is not to put up tax.' I repeat: the Prime Minister said, `to maintain the tax to GDP ratios we roughly have at the moment. We have been through this little debating saga on umpteen previous occasions, and nobody is fooling anybody. The government will do what it is fiscally responsible to do. People know that we have presided over the recovery of the economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —How is your approval rating in Holt?
—Senator Alston, you asked this question.

—We have got more than 400,000 Australians back to work since April last year. We have got a growth rate at the moment, combined with an inflation rate and an investment rate, that is going to produce a sustainable high level of recovery in this country.

PARA.TAB: It is no good talking about the government's position without bearing in mind just how totally and comprehensively fiscally irresponsible the opposition has been. We have Mr Costello, the opposition's treasury spokesman, saying—he subsequently denied it, but it is there in black and white—that he is going to rip the entire $11.7 billion deficit out of the economy in one fell swoop. If anyone goes down that particular path, he would need to appreciate what the implications would be if a deficit reduction exercise of that scale were applied across the board.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. This again is irrelevant to the question that was asked.
—You can't cop it.

—We will debate the government's economic record any day it likes. The question that was asked related to the government and the Prime Minister, in particular, misleading the Australian people before the last election on taxes. Why should that not be the question that is answered rather than what the minister is trying to debate now? I ask you, Mr President, to bring him back to the question that he was asked and have him assure the Australian people that the Prime Minister is not going to lie again.
—I have made it clear before that in exchanges across the floor over matters like this it is clearly appropriate to canvass a range of options. Some of those options may include opposition policies.
—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. It is one thing to condone robust debate, and I do not think any of us shy away from that.
—You do. You would run 100 miles.

—I am indebted to you, Mr President. What I am saying is very simply that in our approach to fiscal management we are not going to adopt the policy course that has been suggested by the opposition. We are not going to adopt a situation where we can simultaneously go to the public and promise something like between $1 billion and $3 billion worth of extra expenditure outlays on public hospitals, tertiary education, infrastructure, police and Aboriginal housing, plus simultaneously promise somewhere between $7 billion and $9 billion worth of tax breaks in terms of exemption of interest, health care rebate, tax and family payment system changes and capital gains tax changes. We are not going to go to the electorate and say that, in the present condition of the economy, we can afford to pump back into the economy somewhere between $6.7 billion and $9.2 billion worth of tax breaks, which is how we cost that particular package the opposition came up with, and another $1 billion to $3 billion of outlay additions, which is how we cost the other things the opposition has gone on the record about, plus at the same time say that we can cut the entire $11.7 billion deficit out of the way.
—Mr President, I rise on a point of order.
—To do that would be to give ourselves a $20 billion fiscal task—
—Order! Senator Hill.
—and we are not going to accept that particular prescription.
—Order! Senator Evans, there is a point of order. You do not help your cause by not ceding when there is a point of order taken.

—He should exercise a little common courtesy for a change. He was asked: can the Australian people this time expect the tax promises to be kept or are taxes going to be raised? That was the question he was asked and that is the question he should answer.
—I have ruled on that already.

—The reason I refused to give the floor to him was that I knew he was not going to make a point of order. He would be breaking his duck if he did. It has been a long time since we have heard one. —I rise to a point of order. The clock has been stopped for 30 seconds.
—The minister's time has expired.

—You will get it. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I understand that the Department of Defence has been considering a proposal to sink the HMAS Derwent off the Western Australian coast and to use the wreck for the training of divers. Could the minister advise the Senate whether a decision has been reached on this project and whether there have been any developments?

—Mr President, there has been considerable publicity over the last couple of months regarding the future of the decommissioned destroyer escort, HMAS Derwent. Some honourable senators may be aware that ship survivability trials have been carried out on the Derwent near the naval base at Garden Island in Western Australia. Those tests, which have provided a rare opportunity for the Royal Australian Navy and DSTO, will produce very useful information for future navy ships and operations.

PARA.TAB: I have been informed by the Chief of the Naval Staff that the combined effects of the various tests and detonations on board the Derwent have been such that the ship is now too dangerous to be suitable for use as a diving wreck. I know that many people will be disappointed with the outcome but the risks are simply too great.

Given the state of the ship, it was proposed to sink the vessel in very deep water, some 35 nautical miles off the coast. But I am pleased to say that agreement in principle has now been reached between the navy and the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency to sink the Derwent a lot closer to shore, some 12 nautical miles off Rottnest Island. I understand that the wreck will become an attractive environment for game fish and other marine life, not that I ever expect to actually see it.

Whilst there is no immediate prospect of satisfying the many diving enthusiasts in Western Australia and elsewhere, it has been decided—Senator Jones and Senator Teague will especially appreciate this, I think—that HMAS Swan, the next large navy ship to be decommissioned, will be earmarked for disposal as a diving wreck off the Western Australian coast near Rockingham.

HMAS Swan is planned to retire from service in June 1996. As with any ship of its size, it will need to be prepared for sinking as a diving wreck, and with less than two years before the Swan becomes surplus to defence requirements, diving associations now can prepare with absolute certainty for its availability in two years time.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. With the focus of question time on increasing or not increasing the overall tax burden, I remind the minister that when the government brought the top income tax rate into line with the company tax at 49 per cent in 1985, the then Treasurer, Mr Keating, claimed that this alignment would `in a stroke . . . make a whole host of tax avoidance devices futile'. Now that the company rate has been dropped to 33 per cent and the top personal rate is 47 cents in the dollar, has not this `whole host of tax avoidance devices' so mentioned come back into play? In particular, to what degree is the incentive for professionals and others to set themselves up as companies now being used to avoid tax, and how much is this contributing to the budget deficit? Is the government concerned about this abuse of the tax laws?

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Do opposition senators not care about tax avoidance? Is the government considering strengthening the anti-avoidance provisions of the tax laws to deal with this issue?

—Senator Kernot certainly started her question correctly. When we came to power we did inherit a leaky, creaky tax system that dribbled all over the place with tax avoidance and we have cleaned that all up, and that is in fact a monument to the tax reform achievements of this government. We reduced company tax down to the level of 33 per cent for economic competitive reasons. That puts Australia in the lowest area of taxing nations in the OECD—I think if we are not the lowest we are very close to being the lowest—and it certainly puts us in touch with Asian business tax regimes as well, particularly considering not just the tax rate itself but also the depreciation regime that we have. So they were the reasons for the reduction in company tax.

PARA.TAB: One of the great reforms we made to the tax system as well was the imputation system—I think Senator Kernot would agree—where company tax is effectively a withholding tax for shareholders and when the dividends are distributed they will pay the full marginal personal tax rate of a full 47 per cent. That guarantees, I think, the system against leakage.

Senator Kernot in her question, as I heard it, asked me whether there is an incentive in the system for professionals to incorporate as companies. Yes, there is an incentive in the system, that is true; it acts in that way. But the effect of the dividend withholding tax should in the end mean that they pay their tax in full.

Senator Kernot asked whether the government is concerned about abuse in the system. Yes, we are. We are a government that has reformed the tax system to try to end abuse. We constantly monitor the effectiveness of the taxation system to identify areas of abuse and legislate for corrective action where necessary. I indicate to the Senate that a package of bills is in fact due here shortly. Those bills pick up some areas where the Taxation Office believes that there is the potential for tax avoidance. But in any case in this area I think one has to have regard to the operation of the imputation system as a method of applying tax here to prevent abuse and leakage from the system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In 1985 the government aligned the company tax and the top income tax rate. At the same time the government repealed a whole lot of anti-avoidance measures. So, I am asking: does not the new non-alignment require the government to look again now at opportunities for avoidance?
—As I am saying, we did that for the reason of competitiveness and we now have a very competitive tax regime. But as to the question of avoidance, that is something—
—You are in favour of higher taxes.

—We are the lowest taxed nation in the OECD, Senator. We are indeed. The only country that was below us was Turkey and it got there because it revised upwards by 30 per cent its GDP ratio, if you would only note it. However, as to Senator Kernot's question, we constantly monitor the tax system to identify areas of avoidance and correct them.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I refer the minister to recent reports that the proposed compulsory purchasing of recycled paper for Commonwealth departments has been delayed at least six months. Can the minister confirm that these reports are true and, if so, can he indicate the reasons for this delay? Given that the termination of the concessional rate of sales tax on recycled products was designed to coincide with the implementation of the government policy for compulsory purchase of recycled paper goods, will there be a provision to give a concessional rate to paper recyclers until the policy is implemented? Can the minister advise what proportion of paper currently used in Commonwealth departments is Reflex brand paper which is produced at the Burnie mill in Tasmania?

—The Prime Minister's statement on the environment made in December 1992 included a commitment that a purchasing target of 90 per cent for certain prescribed categories of paper products—including, for example, notepads, desk calendars and photocopy paper—is to be met by the end of the 1995-96 financial year. There has been a delay in developing the criteria for environmentally preferred paper which I had hoped the government would have been able to finalise earlier in the year. However, there is still sufficient time to allow a purchasing scheme to be put in place by the end of 1995-96. In the meantime, the interim voluntary arrangements which are in place for identifying paper products acceptable for inclusion in voluntary purchasing targets will continue.

PARA.TAB: Arriving at appropriate final criteria for environmentally preferred paper is proving to be extremely difficult. Ours is not a unique situation. Over the past two years the European Union has also attempted to develop environmental criteria for paper products and is encountering problems similar to those that the EPA is grappling with in Australia. The issues encompass matters such as forestry, employment, trade, energy, air and water emissions, recycling and wastes. I have taken the view that it is better to get this policy right rather than hurry the process. Representatives of the pulp and paper industry and key conservation organisations recently held promising meetings on these questions. Unfortunately, those discussions, although identifying some areas of agreement, have reached an impasse, but the EPA is working to negotiate a workable proposal.

Since the Prime Minister's statement, significant changes have occurred within the Australian paper industry. The Pulp and Paper Manufacturers Federation of Australia has announced initiatives to achieve world-class utilisation of waste paper. In addition, the PPMFA members have announced decisions to invest $170 million in expanded or new recycling facilities in Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland.

I will now turn to the second part of Senator Margetts's question. The sales tax concession on some, not all, products made from 100 per cent recycled paper was removed in June 1992—well before the Prime Minister's statement concerning environmentally preferred paper. The decision to remove the sales tax concession on 100 per cent recycled tissue paper, exercise books and paper bags was based on a 1991 report by the Industry Commission which questioned the effectiveness of the concession and identified a number of adverse effects. In September 1992 the government agreed to provide transitional assistance to certain recycled paper manufacturers that had made investments based on the sales tax concession. Transitional assistance was provided for three years, with any further assistance to be subject to review by the EPA. That review will be completed shortly.

In response to the final part of Senator Margetts's question, which asked about the proportion of paper used that is of the Reflex brand, I do not have the information to answer that question. I will take it on notice and ask the Minister for Administrative Services to provide that information to Senator Margetts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the minister to indicate whether he is aware that most of the source material used to produce the Reflex paper currently being used in Commonwealth departments is from fringes of the Tarkine wilderness area in Tasmania. The minister also mentioned trade as being one of the issues that militate against making environmental policy decisions. Can the minister tell us whether this means that there is a problem with their being GATT inconsistent?

—Senator Margetts's first question asked me about the proportion of paper of the Reflex brand that is used in Commonwealth departments. I have indicated that that is something that is obviously properly a matter for the Minister for Administrative Services. I will take on notice the question that she has raised in relation to the source of the resource for the production of that particular paper. It may not come as a surprise to Senator Margetts that I do not have that information in my back pocket and I am unable to give it to her during question time today. I will discuss with my colleague Senator McMullan on his return whether there are any implications in the trade area, but I really have nothing to add to what is already on the public record in that regard.

—It is halfway around the world and it is of no interest to you.

PARA.TAB: Ukraine's adherence to the NPT as a state that inherited nuclear weapons from the former USSR is a particularly valuable contribution in itself to the achievement and promotion of global nuclear disarmament. The decision has special significance as the international community approaches the NPT review and extension conference to be held in New York next April and May.

We in the Australian government firmly believe that the NPT should be extended indefinitely. Ukraine's accession is testimony to the fact that the vast majority of the world's nations consider that their security interests are enhanced by forswearing nuclear weapons absolutely.

As for the other implication of yesterday's decision, it removes the last remaining obstacle under the Lisbon protocol to the START I treaty commencing into force. START provides for further deep cuts in the American and Russian strategic nuclear arsenals and will produce the result, when it is implemented, of wiping out the last 20 years of the nuclear arms race.

France will likewise provide a security assurance.Australia very warmly welcomes all those developments which are of immense significance for the future peace of this planet.

ANSWER.PARA: SENATOR REID'S QUESTION ON VIETNAM FLOOD RELIEF

Senator Reid asked yesterday about allegations of interference by the Vietnamese Government in flood relief being provided by the Unified Vietnamese Buddhist Church (UVBC) to areas of the western provinces badly affected by floods in October, and the arrest of some UVBC members as a result.
While indicating yesterday that I was not aware of the particular circumstances to which Senator Reid referred, I undertook to look into them.
Our Embassy in Hanoi is not able at the moment to supply any independent verification of the claims.

The claims derive solely to date from a report of 6 November by the Vietnam Committee on Human Rights, an expatriate Vietnamese organisation based in Paris, highly critical of the Vietnamese Government and not all of whose reports of human rights violations in the past have proved to be accurate.

The essence of that report was that on 5 November, a group of around 360 UVBC monks, nuns and their followers gathered in Ho Chi Minh City, with 10 vehicles, intent on transporting food, blankets and medicines raised by the UVBC to the Mekong Delta for distribution to flood victims.

The group was allegedly intercepted by Vietnamese security police before they left Ho Chi Minh City, and were forced to disperse. Several of the group's leaders were reportedly arrested and three are said to remain in detention.
These allegations elicited on 9 November a communique from the Fatherland Front, the official umbrella group for non-governmental organisations, including religious ones, in Vietnam.
(The UVBC is not affiliated to the Fatherland Front as it is a banned organisation. The Vietnam Buddhist Church, set up in 1981, is the legal body representing Vietnam's buddhists.)

The 9 November communique in effect denied that any arrests or harassment occurred, although it also made the point that any aid to flood victims, which it was encouraging, had to be channelled through the Fatherland Front.

Our Embassy in Hanoi has spoken to other diplomatic missions and interested journalists, none of whom can shed much light on the allegations. Vietnamese officials concede that a "situation" had arisen in the south in which they claim that the UVBC was trying to organise a "propaganda campaign" using flood relief activities as a cover. Officials maintain, however, that no arrests were made, and that monks and religious were "asked" to return to their home pagodas and to abandon their campaign.
Our Embassy will continue to seek further details.
As I indicated yesterday, religious persecution remains a serious concern which the Government regularly takes up with the Vietnamese authorities, and we will continue to do so.
We will certainly do so again if any truth is established in the latest reports raised by Senator Reid—
particularly as they relate to alleged interference in the delivery of humanitarian relief to flood victims for which the Vietnamese Government had already sought international assistance.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill recognises that Australia has the worse extinction record of native mammals of any country on Earth in recent history and that species extinctions are still occurring at an alarming rate.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should support Commonwealth Threatened Species legislation which uses the full powers given to it by the Australian Constitution and which provides the necessary financial resources to halt the loss of species on this, the oldest continent on earth.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Forests: Western Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That the ancient and irreplaceable native forests in the South West of Western Australia are being destroyed by logging for woodchipping, that many species in these forests are in danger of extinction, and that Federal Government intervention is urgently needed to protect our natural heritage.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in parliament assembled, should call on the Federal Government to:
1.immediately use its powers to protect Hawke, Sharpe, Giblett and Rocky blocks and all other high conservation value and old growth forests in the South West of Western Australia,
2.refuse to renew woodchip export licences unless it is guaranteed that the wood comes from tree crops, agroforestry or plantations and,
3.take steps to ensure the rapid transfer of the wood products industry from all native forests and on to plantations, tree crops and agroforestry.

PETITION.TITLE: Mifepristone
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned showeth:

(1) That the trials of the abortifacient drug Mifepristone (RU486) are against the public interest in that they use women as guinea pigs for trials of a drug which causes death to the unborn future citizens and adds undue risk to the health of women.
(2) That when RU486 is used with a prostaglandin it exposes women to a disproportionate risk of pain, bleeding and more serious complications.
(3) That when RU486 is used as a `morning after pill' its effect is abortifacient in that it stops implantation of a human embryo, a future citizen, in the womb.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will legislate to ban the importation and use of RU486 in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Military Aid to Indonesia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned expresses our concern over the issue of East Timor.
Your petitioners urge the Senate to:

PETITION.PARA: 1.Ban all military aid to Indonesia because of its illegal occupation of East Timor and the gross abuse of human rights to its people.
2.Do not pursue foreign policy with Indonesia at the expense of human rights violations in East Timor.
3.Reverse the decision of the Australian recognition of Indonesia as ruler of East Timor.

DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: Attendance of Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that general business notice of motion No. 1264 standing in my name and relating to the attendance of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs before the Joint Standing Committee on Migration be taken as formal.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion standing in the name of the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Hill, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to general business notice of motion No. 1264 standing in the name of Senator Short for this day, ordering the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to attend and give evidence before the Joint Standing Committee on Migration.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many reasons why Senator Bolkus should be required to appear before the Joint Standing Committee on Migration for its inquiry into the Immigration Review Tribunal appointments. The Senate will be failing in its responsibility if it does not adopt this motion to require the minister to appear before the Joint Standing Committee on Migration to give evidence in relation to the committee's inquiry into the Immigration Review Tribunal's appointment processes.

PARA.TAB: Let me outline briefly why the Senate would be abrogating its responsibility if it fails to call the minister before its committee. The first point is that the reference before the committee is a reference from the Senate. It was adopted by resolution of this Senate. It is not just another reference thought up by the committee itself. The Senate therefore has an obligation to itself, indeed to the parliament as a whole, and a responsibility to ensure that the migration committee, which comprises members of the major parties from both the House of Representatives and the Senate, is given every opportunity to complete the task that the Senate itself set it just a few short weeks ago.

The minister is ultimately responsible for appointments to the Immigration Review Tribunal and the processes that precede those appointments. The migration committee cannot be said to have fully completed its inquiry unless it has heard from the one person who must be regarded as the principal witness—namely, the minister. He minister has so far refused to appear before the committee. He has, therefore, deliberately and wilfully flouted the decision of the Senate to have the committee conduct the inquiry.

In doing so, the minister has joined a long string of ministers from this arrogant government who have stamped on the rights and the responsibilities of the elected parliament of this nation; who have said, in effect, that it is the executive that is paramount in this nation, not the elected parliament. Remember the Prime Minister asserting that question time is a privilege bestowed on the parliament by the executive, not a basic democratic right of the elected representatives of the people?

Senator Bolkus's refusal to appear before the migration committee is merely another illustration of this dangerous anti-democratic arrogance of the government. Are we in this place going to let him get away with that? The standing orders of the Senate quite clearly contemplate the Senate requiring the minister to appear before an inquiry established by the Senate—which is, of course, what my motion attempts to do.

Although there exists and has existed opportunity for some questioning of the minister on the matters which are the subject of the standing committee's inquiry, there is certainly not full opportunity. In any event, that point is, to an important extent, a red herring because the joint standing committee will not have in the official transcript or records of its inquiry anything from the minister unless he appears before the committee. It is also relevant that the committee includes members of the House of Representatives as well as senators, so deliberations in the Senate alone, including during question time or during consideration of estimates by a legislation committee, have no direct relevance to the other house.

Although some senators, including me, have been able to ask questions of the minister in the appropriate Senate legislation committee, that committee is not a suitable venue for a full examination with the minister of all the matters that are the subject of the joint standing committee's inquiry. There are many matters that require further consideration, which I am sure the Senate is aware of.

There is another extremely important reason why the minister should appear before the committee, and that is that this parliament passed the Migration Reform Act, which gives to two tribunals within the minister's portfolio, including the Immigration Review Tribunal, greatly enhanced powers over the lives of applicants for immigration to Australia by virtue of the fact that it severely restricts appeals from those tribunals to the courts.

It is essential, therefore, that the clients of the tribunals and the general community have confidence in the professionalism and objectivity of these tribunals. They can have this only if they have confidence in the processes of appointment to the tribunals. That requires transparency and accountability by the minister in the processes that he follows in selecting candidates and in the appointments he eventually makes.

It became increasingly obvious during the hearings of the migration committee that many elements of this vitally important aspect of the terms of reference of this inquiry require further examination, which cannot be done without the appearance of the minister. For that reason, I urge the Senate to adopt this motion.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I, of course, oppose the motion. I have in my hand a video which contains three hours of the proceedings of a Senate legislation committee which sat last night to examine the estimates of the department. Two and a bit hours of that video relate to the whole question that is before this chamber now. I have subjected myself to exhaustive examination. The committee finished at 1.30 this morning. At the end of the proceedings relating to the IRT, Senator Cooney, as chairman of the committee, asked Senator Short, amongst others, whether there were any further questions on the issue. Senator Short said, `No, we've exhausted it.' We have exhausted this. We have exhausted it in this process; we have exhausted it in this place.
—You know that that is wrong.

—No degree of dissembling by Senator Short and no degree of interruption by him will overcome that particular point. I have been examined here; I have been examined in the legislation committee. Any senator could have come to the legislation committee and asked the same questions.

PARA.TAB: Last night's examination came after 14 or 15 hours of deliberation by the joint standing committee. It came on top of questions asked in the Senate. No new evidence had been found against me at all. Not one word was transcribed in the newspapers this morning despite those two and a bit hours of discussion last night on appointments to the tribunals, particularly the IRT. We spent two and a bit hours on the IRT, and there was not one word in the papers and not one bit of new evidence.

It is quite disingenuous again to come in here and say that I am rejecting the power of the Senate. The Senate and its processes have exhaustively examined me. But what we are seeing here is a direct flouting and misrepresentation of the process. One would have thought that, if it were necessary for me to come before a committee, that would have been planned earlier in the committee's proceedings. But on Monday of this week, on the last day and at the last hour before the committee was going to contemplate its final report to this place—and despite the fact that Senator Short asked a question about this a week ago and the committee deliberated on it 12 days ago—Senator Short came in here and gave notice that he was going to move this motion, knowing full well after discussions last week that time this week is limited for all of us. That is why we met exhaustively until 1.30 this morning. Senator Short is the one who is dissembling the facts on this particular issue.

Senator Short also forgot to mention that the committee was set up, has deliberated and has decided it does not want me. That is an important factor in all this as well. I have been exhaustively examined. I have subjected myself to the committee; I have not snubbed the Senate and its processes. In two and a bit hours of discussion on the IRT there was not one word in the press, but on the last day Senator Short came in here and tried in the way he normally does to score political points. No degree of loud wailing and no degree of allegations about lying, interference and whatever will overcome those basic facts.

The other basic fact is that this has been a stunt from the start. People of good quality, people of meritorious service to the public sector and people of great experience on this tribunal have been dragged through this place and other places because they have been appointed in a process which is at law proper and which has in no way thrown up any degree of impropriety in the way that it was pursued by me.This is on the basis of what? It is on the basis of one person in Victoria who has admitted that his motivation was sour grapes, and one group in Victoria, the lawyers, who do not want to concede this area in the interests of diversity. They want to maintain this. This is the worst closed shop that we would ever come across. It is sectional pleading.

TALK.START.PARA: —An exclusive club!

—It is an exclusive club, indeed; more exclusive than the Melbourne Club. When they were asked about all these assertions they made in respect of their submission and in their submission, they said,`Oh well, we just believe Mr Clothier.' No law student would pass law school on the basis of that degree of checking in terms of the submission they put in. In fact, they are almost in contempt of this place by asserting things that they themselves did not check. That has been the motivating factor here—together with all sorts of unfounded conspiracy theories in respect of this.

PARA.TAB: People have been bagged here because they might have been married to someone. They have been bagged here essentially because they are not members of that legal club. Michelle Scott, for instance, was mentioned as a person of no standing, no qualifications. But she is a former senior member of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal in Western Australia. Those things have been deliberately ignored by Senator Short as he tries to paint a picture and as he deceives his way through the public with—I will not say the passive compliance—the ignorant writings of some of the journalists in the gallery who should know better.

Hearsay, supposition, so-called evidence, and the evidence of disgruntled applicants have been paraded as fact—all driven by the motivation of sour grapes. I am not flouting this particular place. I have subjected myself to it here and in the estimates committee, where any senator could have come, exhaustively until 1.30 this morning. Quite honestly, this is a political stunt at the taxpayers' expense and at the expense of the individuals whose reputation Senator Short wants to bag. That should not be the process of this place. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion ought to be passed without debate. This motion is about accountability and it is about the refusal of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) to appear before the Joint Standing Committee on Migration.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bolkus has said in his defence that he appeared before the estimates committee. If appearance before an estimates committee in relation to the expenditure of a department is to abrogate responsibility from a joint parliamentary committee, there is something seriously wrong with our processes, because you know, Mr Deputy President, how limited the right to question is during estimates and how much many ministers, especially Senator Bolkus, utilise every opportunity to try to limit the right to question during estimates.

Senator Bolkus has a reputation in this place—in fact, I am sure Senator Bolkus prides himself on his reputation in this place—for trying to be obstructive during estimates. An appearance before an estimates committee is no substitute for an appearance before a duly constituted committee of this parliament which has had a reference to conduct an inquiry into a particular matter. Senator Bolkus knows it. It is a sad reflection on this minister's capacity to understand the role of a joint parliamentary committee that he would presume to think it is sufficient merely to turn up at an estimates hearing and obfuscate his way through that at the best of times.

It is no defence that Senator Bolkus comes before the Senate and waves a videotape with goodness knows what on it and says, `I appeared before the estimates committee. I don't have to answer any more of these questions.' If appearance before an estimates committee is all that is required, the opportunity to examine ministers in this place will be limited to twice a year. It will be limited to when the estimates next come around. We will be constantly hassled by the minister and the government members on the committee to hurry up and get on to the next subject. That is not parliamentary scrutiny, and honourable senators all well know that that is not parliamentary scrutiny. Unfortunately, that is far from parliamentary scrutiny.

Senator Bolkus's next defence was a defence on the merits, supposedly, of his case. He said, `But these are all people of good standing.' If these are all people of good standing, what is the point of Senator Bolkus's reluctance to appear before the committee? If these are all people of good standing, what is the problem with the inquiry going ahead? Surely the assertion that an appointee is a person of good standing is not enough.

The Australian Democrats have said many times that it is appropriate we look at the manner in which an administration conducts itself and at the people who are appointed to positions. The Democrats have supported us on a number of occasions—the former Comptroller-General of Customs, Mr Frank Kelly, is a case in point—in relation to these matters where it was considered appropriate to look at the qualifications of the persons who were appointed to particular positions of office. Therefore, it is no defence for Senator Bolkus merely to assert that these are people of good standing.

The inquiry has gotten to the point where the committee wants to hear from the minister the grounds on which certain people were appointed. If that is not allowed, all we get is a minister evading his responsibility—evading

SPEECH.PARA: his responsibility to the cost of good administration of immigration in this country. That is wrong.

PARA.TAB: That is why I say that this motion should be supported. Senator Short's motion No. 1264 should, in fact, be passed by this Senate so that the minister can be compelled to meet his responsibilities; so that people outside this place have an assurance that good administration is being safeguarded by this parliament; and so that we can be assured that this Labor government, which has such a reputation for cheating, dishonesty and corruption, does not continue it further. That is why this motion is so important. That is why the suspension of standing orders should be supported. That is why Senator Short's motion No. 1264 should be supported for the good administration of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats supported the reference that is now the subject of this debate because we thought that the minister had a case to answer and that it should be investigated by the committee. The committee has heard evidence. The committee has made an informal request to the minister, which the minister has refused. A formal motion to request the minister to appear before the committee has been rejected, but we must be cognisant of the fact that that motion was passed along party lines. On the basis of formal procedures, the minister was not requested to appear before the committee. The Australian Democrats have been in these sorts of situations before: ministers have been asked to be accountable to Senate committees, a responsibility which they have tried to avoid. Indeed, we feel extremely strongly about it.

PARA.TAB: There are a couple of other factors in this case, however, that need to be taken into account. There was a meeting before the legislation committee dealing with estimates last night and, in Senator Short's own words, Senator Short grilled the minister for an hour and a half on the questions that he would put to him through the committee or before the committee. On this substantive issue the Democrats have decided not to support Senator Short's motion. We believe that it would amount to duplication of effort and be a waste of time. I must admit that it smacks somewhat of a witch hunt when this opportunity in substance was available to the opposition at the time, to now take the view it wants to re-run the questions and the whole debate again.

Senator Short was kind enough to provide me with written information detailing his reasons why the minister should go before the committee. This included some questions that were to be put to the minister in a fairly general way. I understand that the questions contained in the advice from Senator Short have already been put to the minister.

I believe that in the present circumstances the proper procedure would be for last night's questions and answers to be submitted to the committee. The Hansard report is available. As chairman of that committee, Senator McKiernan might wish to give the chamber an assurance that the committee will reconvene, examine the questions and answers set out in Hansard and incorporate the content of those questions and answers in its report, which I believe is due to be handed down tomorrow.

There is still time for that course to be taken. If the minister is saying—and it is an argument which conditionally, on balance and somewhat uneasily we accept—that we do not wish to duplicate effort, then let us ensure that the results of that effort are incorporated in the committee's report. If that is not to happen, I feel there is a case for the matter to proceed further. But as matters stand today, and in view of the fact that neither I nor anybody else has been able to examine the Hansard of last night's proceedings, and as it appears efforts would be duplicated, the Democrats are not disposed to support the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I enter the substance of the debate, I wish to respond to Senator's Spindler's request that the Hansard of last evening of the proceedings before the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee relating to the appointments to the Immigration Review Tribunal be appended to the report that is scheduled to be presented in the parliament on Thursday of this week. I will examine whether it is possible to take that course under the standing orders. I am not aware whether it is possible so to do.

PARA.TAB: I believe that it will create a problem because last evening, prior to the legislation committee undertaking its estimates review, the Joint Standing Committee on Migration finalised its report on the terms of reference which had been referred to the committee on motion by Senator Short on 20 October this year. Certainly 20 October was some weeks ago, and the other date one should bear in mind, 15 August, is now of course some months ago and that was when these issues—the subject matter of the terms of reference—were first raised.

It is important to remember those dates because some concerns were expressed by questions on notice by Senator Short about the appointment processes way back in August. On 20 October, following some debate in this place, Senator Short moved reference to the Joint Standing Committee on Migration. The committee undertook its task of holding a public inquiry on the terms of reference. The committee held three public hearings—extended public hearings where, among other people, the principal member of the Immigration Review Tribunal, Ms Pam O'Neil, was before the committee for some five hours of detailed questioning. The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs was before the committee for six hours.

Going back to August, I understand a request for the minister to appear before the committee was not made until the dying hours of the very last day of the public hearings. That request was in addition to the days set aside for the witnesses that the committee had agreed to call before it. I ask the Senate to take that matter into consideration when voting or deciding on this motion. Quite apart from that, the committee has had other matters to consider involving scrutiny of what relates to the terms of reference. I am trying to be careful because the matters on which the committee determined last night are not public and will not become public until Thursday of this week when the report is presented to parliament. I do not want to divulge the contents of that report or enter into debate upon them.

The wheels have now turned and the cart has moved along at a considerable pace. In fact, the cart has passed by but Senator Short has not recognised that fact. This last gasp effort to reopen the committee process should be doomed to failure. I do not know how the committee, in this last week of Senate sittings for 1994, could undertake the task, were the task to be given to it, and present its report prior to the conclusion of the sittings. Furthermore, I am not sure about the standing of the motion if it were to be carried and how it would apply to the committee. It is a joint committee made up of members of the other place as well as senators from this chamber. The committee has taken the decision not to invite the minister to appear before it.

I believe that the motion should be defeated by the Senate. I will undertake to do my best to observe Senator Spindler's request that the minutes of last night's proceedings before the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee be appended to the report of the joint standing committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a brief statement.
—Senator Spindler, would you give some indication of that which you intend to refer to?

—I wish to advise the chamber of the advice I have received from the clerk on the appropriateness or possibility under the standing orders of the committee, even at this stage, dealing with last night's Hansard committee report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The advice I have received, in answer to the doubts that were expressed by Senator McKiernan, is that there is no procedural bar to the committee reopening its considerations and considering, not just appending to the report, the evidence that was provided to the legislation committee last night.

PARA.TAB: There may be certain logistical problems—I appreciate that—but I will proffer the advice from the clerk that there is certainly no procedural bar. I ask Senator McKiernan to give an assurance now that the material will be brought before the committee for consideration and incorporation in the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I give that assurance if it accords with the standing orders of the parliament.

—I rise to indicate where the Greens stand in relation to this motion. We do not support it at this juncture. However, we believe that some very important principles, which we agree with, underlie the moving of that motion. The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) should be accountable for the ways in which these appointments are made. There should be a process by which his testimony can be brought before a joint committee or a Senate committee or evaluated in terms of the basis or the process by which appointments are made. If for no other reason than allegations are made that there are political motivations underlying the appointment, there should be some clear means of asserting that that is untrue. We do not have that clarity unless we have a better accountability procedure.

PARA.TAB: In my view, it is quite amiss that the Joint Committee on Migration did not seek and gain before it the minister's witness. That was clearly the appropriate way to go. To now ask the Senate to force that to happen causes me two problems. Firstly, I have been part of a joint committee which has received a request of the Senate, and I have not been impressed by the kind of regard in which those recommendations or requests are held. Secondly, I do not feel that the committee that it is being referred to at the moment has shown itself to be doing its job if it has not already interviewed the minister with regard to this matter. That is why I do not particularly support the motion.

The questioning that occurred in estimates last night attempted to look at the content of the concerns. It is well and good if the committee is able to reopen its considerations prior to submitting a report on the matter and look at the testimony of the minister that was given last night. However, I do not feel that addresses the procedural point, which is that a minister need not be requested by the Senate to appear. If a minister is requested to appear, he or she should do so. I feel that it may be the wrong committee and not the right time at which to push it in this way.

I indicate my support in general for the principle that ministers should be able to appear before committees and give an account of how they came to their determinations, especially with regard to a statutory body. I would have felt much more sympathetic towards a Senate committee that looked at these issues. That might have been a better way to go. In this instance, we will not support the motion. But I am pleased to record that in some way the minister will give testimony to the committee, even though it will be by a very windy path.
