TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The question of defence housing is something which has been of importance to me since the day I came into this parliament. In fact, a large slab of my maiden speech, which I was re-reading the other day, was directed at the failure of this government and preceding governments to provide decent housing for Defence Force personnel. In that speech I pointed to the totally unsatisfactory situation of navy families living in Sydney who did not have a hot water service. In 1986 I thought that was a pretty incredible thing to have to tell the parliament of Australia.

PARA.TAB: The opposition put a lot of pressure on the government. There was an inquiry into personnel conditions of service, and I must acknowledge the fact that the government did decide to move. The government has been facilitated by the total support of the opposition in respect of the introduction of the Defence Housing Authority. As a result of the measures that have been put in place as a result of that move, we can at last say that Australia's servicemen and women now have a chance of living in decent accommodation. And so they should.

I am glad to see the recognition given by the Auditor-General that approximately 10,000 substandard houses have been replaced since the authority commenced operations in 1988. The authority also owns or leases from the private market housing that is provided to members. Defence pays a market rent to the authority for those houses.

What is not always realised is that Defence Force members do pay rent for their housing. I found a fairly common assumption among some civilians that Defence Force personnel get free housing. They get nothing of the sort. However, there is a rent subsidy. That subsidy is partly designed to deal with the question of the substandard nature of the accommodation. It is also intended to recognise that Defence Force personnel are moved to a place that suits their employer; it is not necessarily a place that they would move to of their own accord or a place that is of their own choice.

I believe that the imposition of the fringe benefits tax on this housing is ludicrous. I criticised it when it was introduced; I still criticise it today. What disturbs me is that we have people in the Department of Finance sending a bill to the Department of Defence for fringe benefits tax; then we have people in the Department of Defence doing the calculations and sending the money off to the Department of Finance; then we have the Department of Finance actually supplementing the Department of Defence's budget by the amount of the fringe benefits tax. This arrangement could only be devised by a public organisation! A private organisation surely could not be so stupid as to administer its affairs in that manner.

Having said all that, the fringe benefits tax gets included in the calculations of the cost of defence housing. To give the Auditor-General his due, having included it in, he then deducted it out again in order to make his points. I make the point that this tax is a nonsense and it should be got rid of. If the minister, Senator Ray, were anything like a man he would stand up to the finance minister and get rid of fringe benefits tax impositions on the entitlements of Defence Force personnel. They are conditions of service: they reflect the requirements that go with the job.

I am disturbed by two or three things that are in the Auditor-General's report. I will be as brief as I can in canvassing those issues on which I would like to make a comment. In one of the items the Auditor-General refers to reviews of ADF accommodation and the possibility of a cash payment to members in lieu of subsidised housing. He points out that the cash subsidy option has a number of advantages in terms of simplicity and freedom of choice but that it could have significant implications to the Defence Housing Authority, and tax considerations would be an important element.

I worry about the cash subsidy option. Although it is superficially attractive, I am concerned that cash subsidies tend to stay fixed and they tend to be devalued over the passage of time. Uncaring governments could allow that subsidy to be whittled away to little or nothing. The current arrangement has a certainty about it and we have all become used to it. I would want to be convinced of the value of any change before I could endorse it. That question is yet to be decided. The Auditor-General said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there is a need for Defence to seek Government endorsement of the nature and level of ADF housing assistance as soon as recent reviews, including the study of a cash subsidy option, are finalised.

I would ask the government to be as open as it possibly can about these reviews and about its position on them. This is a matter which is always of great concern to Defence Force families. It is something which vitally affects their standard of living. The easiest way for them to be fearful is for a rumour to sweep around as to what the government's position will be as a result of these reviews of the housing assistance arrangements. I alert the minister to the real concern that there is in Defence Force families about that issue. There is a need to address that concern sensitively.

PARA.TAB: I want to talk about scales and standards, too. Over the years, this has been a very vexed issue and defence force personnel have paid a heavy price. A great number of houses which are now considered to be substandard were provided in the 1950s. They were prefabricated cottages which were pretty consistent with the standard of housing in Australia after the end of the war when there were housing and material shortages and, as a result, fibro houses and little wooden cottages were the norm around Australian suburbs.

At that time, therefore, housing of this prefabricated nature which was provided for defence force families was pretty consistent with community standards. As the years passed and we got into the 1980s—and now into the 1990s in a few cases—defence force families were still living in these houses which had become completely out of kilter with community norms. I am concerned at the flagging of the comparison with community standards. The Auditor-General said in the report:

SPEECH.PARA: The ANAO raised the need for Defence to ensure that ADF housing standards were consistent with current community standards for civilians in similar income groups.
He went on to talk about the need:
to ensure that dwellings do not exceed defence requirements.

The problem here is that similar income groups in the community are not necessarily reflective of similar skill levels. For example, we have very highly skilled people. One of them may hold the rank of corporal, have several children and be entitled to welfare supplements. So the income of defence force personnel does not truly reflect their importance to the organisation they serve. They are professionals. If we are too determined to tie the community standards and similar income groups to the sort of housing that we give to other ranks, we may house them poorly in comparison with their abilities and importance to us as a nation. We should be very careful that, in making sure that dwellings do not exceed Defence requirements, we properly recognise the need to maintain good standards.

PARA.TAB: We have to be careful. We do not want to go back to the bad old days when anything was good enough for the defence forces. We have moved from that position since 1988. The Auditor-General pointed out that:

SPEECH.PARA: A major cause of the shortage of Group A houses appears to be that the DHA, with Defence concurrence, has provided houses of a standard in excess of Defence requirements.

I think that is in the eye of the beholder. I am very glad that Defence was prepared to put its service personnel into houses which were above the strictly written standards for the various ranks. I hope that Defence and the government continue to do that.

PARA.TAB: Group A housing is fairly inexpensive housing and of a fairly poor level by Australian standards today. The Defence Housing Authority maintains that it is uneconomic to provide group A housing for Defence because, for example, it has a very poor resale value. It is not the sort of housing that most Australians want to buy. That is an important matter for consideration by the Defence Housing Authority in the resalability that is needed. Because, as Defence needs change, it needs to be able to turn over defence houses and sell them on the open market. So the houses should have some relevance to the standards which Australians expect when going out to buy a house.

I have mentioned the high wastage rates in 1986 and Manfred Cross's report on personnel wastage in the ADF. In the government's response to that report, there was a clear indication that the most important thing in the provision of housing assistance to ADF members would be the maintenance of the greatest extent of choice possible. I am sad to see that the Auditor-General said that this does not appear to have been fully implemented. The Auditor-General recommended that:

SPEECH.PARA: members should be allowed a greater degree of choice in the type, cost and location of housing they occupy, consistent with satisfying Defence operational requirements.

I am very glad to see that spelled out, but I am slightly disturbed at the suggestion that the government's position does not appear to have been fully implemented. I urge the minister to look at that issue.

PARA.TAB: The cost to Defence of vacant houses and of the allocation of inappropriate housing according to the Auditor-General was $35.5 million in 1993-94. He said that urgent action to reduce these costs is essential. I agree wholeheartedly. Defence dollars are too hard to come by, and there are too many calls on those dollars for any of them to be wasted. If we can reduce the figure from $35.5 million, we should certainly do so. I am glad to see that the Auditor-General has recognised that systems that have been introduced in 1993 should improve the management and control of the housing.

Another matter which I take issue with is the question of the 52 representational houses. These are usually houses which have an important heritage value to our nation. They have been occupied for decades—if not a century—by the defence forces of this nation. They are treasures which we really all own. The Commonwealth has constitutional responsibility for the maintenance of our national heritage. It so happens that Defence meets the cost of maintaining these houses. They are special houses. Perhaps the cost should be borne by the Heritage Commission and not by Defence. The Auditor-General recommended that:

SPEECH.PARA: Defence examine the need for the continued occupancy of each of these expensive properties.

They have to be maintained by somebody. The Commonwealth has owned them for a very long time. The Commonwealth has maintained them very well. Nobody in this country can exceed the Department of Defence in the heritage and environmental standards it is maintaining in places like HMAS Stirling. We have a very good trustee for the maintenance and management of these heritage houses in the defence department.

PARA.TAB: It is not inappropriate that recognition should be given to those who are high achievers in the defence forces of this country. In terms of income, they do not equate to the high achievers in business, but they are critically important to the wellbeing of this nation. Surely their long years of distinguished service can be appropriately recognised by letting them use these houses which belong to the nation.

As I say, the nation has to maintain them anyway. Defence personnel certainly pay rent, although not obviously such as would be sufficient to finance the maintenance of these houses. These are expensive properties to maintain in the sense that historic properties always are. But if the defence department did not do the work, who would? So long as we can find an appropriate mechanism, these houses should be retained for the purposes for which they have long been used.

SPEECH.PARA: The report states:

In May 1989 the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel made a Ministerial Statement requiring the DHA to take over leases arranged under Temporary Rental Allowance (TRA) conditions. Members eligible to rent privately would advise the Authority of the details of suitable accommodation that had been found and the DHA would take out the lease. Bonds paid by individuals would be eliminated and the DHA would manage repairs and maintenance in consultation with the landlord.
As the Auditor-General points out:
The important element of choice was to be preserved.

I find it extraordinary that, although the department and DHA officers initiated some action regarding this matter in 1989, the approach outlined by the minister has not been implemented. I have to ask the minister—and I am very glad that he is here while I am speaking—to have a look at this and be ready to tell us why the 1989 statement by the then Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has not been implemented. There is no explanation given here as to why this is so. I would expect the current Minister for Defence to start asking some questions in his department and be prepared to advise the parliament of the answers.

PARA.TAB: I did chuckle—perhaps chuckle is not too strong to say—at reading the fact that the TRA data has not been readily available to the Auditor-General. I have been through estimates committees over a number of years where data which one would have expected to be basic was not available to the estimates committees.

I would have hoped that by now the Auditor-General would be able to get access to this sort of information, although, to give Defence its due, it actually seems to be getting better at being able to provide some of these details. Perhaps this is just one area the minister has not yet swept out. I urge him to see what can be done about that information that the Auditor-General needed.

The Auditor-General also indicated that in 1994 there were delays in the identification of vacated properties which resulted in Defence incurring unnecessary rental charges of about $700,000. That is extraordinary. If it were not for the fact that the Auditor-General has gone on to say that measures are now in place which should prevent that happening in the future, I would be very much more upset about it than I am.

I am disappointed and I find it extraordinary that, with the numbers of people we have had looking at good management in defence matters across all the programs in the last couple of years or so, it took an Auditor-General's analysis to point out the fact that there was need for action in this area. That waste of $700,000 is a great shame.

The allocations of service housing is another matter to which the Auditor-General referred. I am glad to see that there has been a system introduced which will provide improved management and control of the housing stock.

In conclusion, the standards which had been allowed to drop from the 1950s to the 1980s must not be allowed to happen again. The Defence Force personnel are too important to the future of this country and to the wellbeing of the nation to be disheartened by the poor morale that comes from poor housing and from families being shifted from pillar to post in substandard accommodation. The improvement in housing over the last few years—since 1988 and the introduction of the Defence Housing Authority—is to be welcomed and to be praised.

I would not want to think that attention to every single dollar—although each one of them is important—means that flexibility, choice and high standards would be ignored. We have to proceed prudently as far as the dollar is concerned, but we must recognise that, to maintain people in whom we have invested so heavily for their training, we must give them good housing, we must manage it well and we must be fair to them and give them some choice and flexibility. I am glad that the Auditor-General has made this report. I have a couple of things on which to take issue, but on the whole it is a program which appears to be standing up pretty well.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Reference Committee on rural adjustment, rural debt and rural reconstruction, together with submissions and the transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: On 24 March this year, when the Senate agreed to an inquiry into rural adjustment, rural debt and rural reconstruction, I must admit that I thought it might be difficult for the Rural and Regional Affairs Committee to produce a unanimous report, given the complex and emotive nature of the relevant issues. In its inimitable manner, though, the committee went out and talked to the people in rural Australia about adjustment processes and the heavy burden of debt and its social, economic and ecological impact on farmers, their communities and the land.

PARA.TAB: The committee held 17 public hearings in places ranging from the Murchison in Western Australia, to Charleville in Queensland, to West Wyalong and Gilgandra in New South Wales. We heard evidence from 262 witnesses, several of whom took advantage of the committee's practice of allowing people to come from the audience to have their two-bob's worth. I consider that the unanimous report I have just tabled demonstrates that committee members have listened to rural Australia, have wrestled with major issues and, I am confident, have come up with proposals that will encourage a robust, competitive and sustainable rural sector.

In its report the committee has reached 33 major conclusions and makes 27 specific recommendations. In this chairman's tabling statement it would be impossible for me to address all of these matters. Also, I am mindful that other members of the committee will want to speak to the report at the earliest opportunity. However, I wish to speak briefly on seven major themes running through the report.

Firstly, the focus of the current rural adjustment scheme, known as RAS 92, is towards longer term adjustment measures and, in particular, farm productivity, profitability and sustainability. The committee formed the view that this message has not been relayed to rural Australia and that generally people do not appreciate the fundamental and significant change in focus from assistance measures provided under RAS 88 to adjustment measures based on viability and long-term profitability in RAS 92.

In response to this situation the committee makes several recommendations relating to the administration and management of the scheme at the Commonwealth and state level. Primarily, the committee is of the view that there needs to be more a consistent and uniform approach to adjustment measures and that guidelines issued by the Commonwealth need to be more prescriptive. This is not meant to hinder flexibility but rather to avoid ambiguities and anomalies in interpretations and results. In turn, this will mean that potential recipients will have a clearer understanding of their eligibility for the entitlements to adjustment programs.

The committee also addressed issues such as access to information, the promotion and delivery of programs and the level of funding. The committee welcomes recent initiatives to make the funding of assistance to exceptional circumstances drought areas demand driven.

In relation to the scheme as a whole, members of the committee are concerned that there are few mechanisms in place to monitor the effectiveness and performance of adjustment measures. Accordingly, we recommend that the establishment of a fully operational management information system must be given urgent attention and that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy should monitor more closely the success or otherwise of programs at grassroots level.

Secondly, the committee considers that, in the short to medium term, several aspects of rural adjustment must be improved and changed. Confusion about the current scheme is so widespread that the government should introduce a revamped scheme based on recommendations made in this report and give that scheme a new name.

Thirdly, the committee indicates that the focus of this revamped rural adjustment scheme should continue to be on farm productivity, profitability and sustainability, but with a principal component being skills enhancement, access to professional advice and the development of financial management, as well as the re-establishment grant.

The fourth matter I wish to address relates to exceptional circumstances. The committee reached the unanimous conclusion that exceptional circumstances should be removed from rural adjustment and made the subject of a separate Commonwealth-state agreement. On this matter we heard persuasive evidence that exceptional circumstances and RAS are mutually exclusive and inconsistent and that exceptional circumstances provisions distort the primary adjustment focus on productivity. The existence of exceptional circumstances within RAS clouds the real purpose of the rural adjustment scheme, as it promotes an assistance flavour—the very element that RAS is seeking to avoid.

The report also recommends that the Commonwealth government define what it means by `exceptional circumstances' but, more particularly, establish a definition of drought that will allow a consistent and clearly enunciated government response when farmers cannot reasonably cope with prolonged dry conditions.

The committee looked at each component of RAS 92 and, where necessary, has made recommendations to improve adjustment measures. For example, we received evidence questioning the effectiveness of interest rate subsidies as an instrument to facilitate rural adjustment. We recommend that the government needs to examine this matter more closely. Similarly, the committee received considerable evidence on re-establishment grants, which are intended to provide an incentive for farmers without prospects to exit with dignity. The members of the committee are not convinced that these objectives are being achieved and recommend that the Commonwealth consider increasing the level of the grant or, alternatively, modifying the current assets threshold so that farming families may exit with more assets. We also recommend that the link between eligibility for the re-establishment grant and jobsearch allowance be abolished.

The sixth matter that I would like to address is a theme that rightly pervades this report, that of skills enhancement and education. The committee is convinced that sound financial and management skills are the key to the reconstruction of rural Australia. Accordingly, the committee recommends that these programs should become a principal component of rural adjustment. This already important issue gains further importance when it is realised that in Australia today the average age of farmers is 58 years. The report recommends that the government should examine whether it is appropriate for rural adjustment programs, particularly the skills enhancement component, to include measures that will encourage young farmers.

In the second part of the report, the committee notes that rural debt is estimated to be $17 billion. This debt is a symptom rather than the cause of more fundamental and deep-seated problems in rural Australia. We consider that improved farm and business management skills are the key to tackling these problems and will result in a strong competitive and sustainable farm sector.

In relation to re-establishment grants, the committee reached the conclusion that skills and training should also be an important part of this adjustment process and therefore recommends that the Commonwealth government should include a specific retraining program in these grants to enable farmers to meet the challenge of leaving the farm with confidence and future prospects.

The final major theme that I wish to address relates to the long term. The committee is of the view that the need for rural adjustment measures and exceptional circumstances provisions should diminish when the Commonwealth government provides an environment that will encourage farmers to adopt a self-reliant, risk management approach to farming. The loudest and clearest message that the committee got from the bush is that farmers do not want handouts, they want to be self-reliant. This environment will be achieved when an attractive income equalisation deposit scheme is introduced and tax measures that adversely affect farmers and rural areas are changed. I sincerely hope that the committee's recommendations on IEDs, tax averaging, provisional tax and tax credits are part and parcel of the package that will be considered by cabinet tomorrow.

As I indicated earlier, the report addresses many issues, only some of which I have dealt with today. Others include: a grassroots regional approach to adjustment; appeal mechanisms; and farm inspections. In the final section of the report, the committee also draws conclusions on the important role that the banks and lending institutions must play in rural Australia and we recommend that the Commonwealth government should examine proposals for a farm debt mediation service. I am sure that these matters will be addressed in more detail by other members of the committee.

Finally, it would be remiss of me not to acknowledge the considerable contribution to this inquiry made by Senator Burns, who chaired the committee until changes to the Senate committee structure were introduced in October of this year. I thank him and the other members of the committee, past and present, for their work on this very important inquiry. I also thank the secretariat—Neil Bessell, Peter Hallahan, John O'Keefe, Jacquie Hawkins and Chris Migus—for the work they have done on this report, and the other workload they have achieved in the last few months. I commend the report to the Senate. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee on the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Bill 1994, together with the transcript of evidence and submissions.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I present the report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Southern Africa and seek leave to move a motion in relation to that report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: It gives me pleasure to present the report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Southern Africa, which took place in July 1994. As the leader of the delegation, Mr Ben Humphreys, said on a number of occasions, it was a delegation of the parliament, meaning that there were representatives of government, being Mr Humphreys and Mr Colin Hollis; two representatives from the opposition, being the deputy leader of the delegation Ms Trish Worth and Mr Richard Evans; a delegate from the Australian Democrats, Senator Coulter; and me.

PARA.TAB: It was a good opportunity for us to see an area of the world which does not receive a lot of attention in this parliament. In recent times we have tended to focus quite narrowly, to my way of thinking, on the Asian region as the area of major interaction between the Australian government and the world. But it seems there are many people who would like to interact more with Australia and southern Africa seems an amazingly obvious place for that to happen. There are similarities in climate and in the problems we face—some problems are different—but we could learn a lot more from each other than we currently do.

We went to four countries during the delegation's visit: Zimbabwe, Namibia, Botswana and South Africa. The reason for that order was so we could talk to people in other countries in southern Africa before talking to those people with the exciting prospect of living in South Africa in a post-election era. We wanted to talk to people who had gone through the process of independence with majority governments to see what lessons they had learned or felt could be learned by South Africa before talking to people in South Africa about what was happening there. That was very exciting.

I guess we all went with different expectations and different areas of interest. In Zimbabwe, I was particularly concerned about the impact of the structural adjustment that came from the level of debt dependence through the IMF and the World Bank. In many countries, especially those in southern Africa, that dependence has meant a push towards exports, a push towards attracting investment and a push for the government to follow a model structural adjustment. In every country it has meant a cut in government spending, a reduction of jobs in the public sector and less money available for social infrastructure and social security. It has also meant a push for production for export. The problem for a delegation with so many interests was that, while we wanted to speak to as many people and find out as much as we possibly could, the ability to go into the rural areas and find out what the issues were at that level was almost non-existent. That was unfortunate.

We were able to talk to people on the ground level about the impact of AIDS in a number of countries. In some countries in southern Africa the official recognition is that there might be one in seven sexually active people who are affected by AIDS. In many cases the only way that they can gain information about those kinds of statistics is when women present for childbirth and they are able to take blood samples then and they are also able to test children who present with symptoms which seem to be indicative of AIDS or HIV positive illnesses. It is a real problem which, to a large extent, is underestimated. It is very difficult address it in a situation where many people, for historical or cultural reasons, find it difficult to talk about the issues of safe sex and multi-partnering and there is a problem about providing and distributing information about safe sex.

Senator Coulter and I were also interested in a number of other issues. We were particularly interested in the impact of decisions about the economy on ecological sustainability and also in finding out what impact the new international trade regimes would have on developing countries. We asked a number of people, both formally and informally, what impact the Uruguay Round of GATT might have. I must say that the majority of people to whom I spoke said that they were not very cognisant of the implications of the Uruguay Round of GATT before it was signed. They felt there was a push for them to be involved and they have in fact been learning more about it since the signing.

But the majority of people that I spoke to answered that the more they heard about it and the more they found out about it, the more they were concerned about the impact on less developed countries, especially places such as Zimbabwe. There were exceptions to this but I believe there is a growing concern that the benefits that are meant to be coming, especially to developing countries, may not happen in that way. People also feel that in intellectual property there may be some very big setbacks in the ability of those owners of ideas and information to be able to manipulate the situation in ways that have adverse consequences on those countries with the least power.

On the trip to Namibia, I was particularly interested to find out how an economy works in the middle of a desert. It was an amazing situation. The thing that struck me most about Namibia was that it was not just a dual economy; in fact it was at least a three-way economy. There was a city which was very much like many European cities. Prices for many of the goods in that city were very much akin to European prices. On the edge of the city were satellite areas for African Namibians. The standard of housing was not of European standard but it was reasonable and some new houses were being developed. But then there were whole areas of Namibia where there were still people starving during droughts and there were some serious problems. There is a very big and growing difference between the rich and the poor in Namibia.

We also were privileged to go to Walvis Bay which was controlled by South Africa for many years and has only recently—earlier this year—been transferred back to Namibia. That is very exciting because it means that the fishing industry of Namibia can now be controlled from the coast of Namibia. There are some problems with over-fishing. I think that in the years of build-up, when perhaps South Africa felt that there was going to be a handover of that particular area, the conservation strategies for the fishing industry were virtually non-existent. So we have a situation where the Namibian government is now looking at how it can build up its fish stocks and try to ensure that it has a sustainable industry.

Botswana, I think for most of us, was an area that we knew little about. I must say that there has never been an Australian parliamentary delegation to Namibia since independence, nor has there been one to Botswana. There have been very few to Zimbabwe, and of course this was the first to South Africa since the change of government. So it was a very important delegation for information. Botswana has become, in many ways, quite Europeanised. To me it is quite sad to see that the culture of many African countries has almost been swallowed up and they are just now beginning to look at how to value their own culture. There is also a huge AIDS problem in Botswana. There are actually posters along the road in Botswana admitting that one in seven of the sexually active population has AIDS.

But South Africa was, I guess, what we were largely working towards in speaking to people from various countries. There are still huge structural problems and huge needs to be addressed. We went to Alexandria, a township which was designed for 60,000 people and has in excess of 200,000. While we were there several houses caught alight in a rather serious fire. Because of the amount of plastic that people had used in trying to build this housing, it was obviously a very toxic fire as well.

The land issues in South Africa are huge. At the moment the South Africans are dealing with rural land issues. They are dealing with the people who have been illegally disenfranchised from land during the period of apartheid and there are still huge problems with equity and land access to be dealt with. A constitutional working group is looking at the problems relating to putting together a constitution for the future.

I think there may be problems in the future. Currently, South African parliamentarians are being elected on a quota basis and at this stage there are no electorates for these parliamentarians. If that were to continue there may be a problem with parliamentary accountability. I presume that in the future it will move to some sort of mixture between proportional representation and electorates, even if it is a group proportional representation or there is a difference between the two houses. I think that will come with time. But what surprised me was the fact that 80 per cent of the workers in South Africa are still paid differential wages according to their race. That is hard to believe. We assume that many of these changes took place automatically but they did not. In Australia we heard that there were some industrial relations problems. There is still a big struggle to be had.

It was the most extraordinary experience. I would like to thank the high commissioner in Zimbabwe, Kerry Sibraa, his wife Julie and his staff for looking after us so well. I would also like to thank the high commissioner in South Africa, Ross Burns, and his staff for looking after us and giving us the briefings. We were looked after so well in each of the countries that we visited: we were the guests of the governments of Zimbabwe, Namibia and Botswana. It was made simpler by the hard work of the secretary of the delegation, Peter Roberts. I should also like to thank Alan Fewster for his work as adviser from the southern Africa desk in Foreign Affairs.

If anything, we have all been converted to the fact that we cannot just look north. We have to look at the other parts of the world. We have to make sure that we build those connections because if we do not we will all be the poorer. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.PARA: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No.2) 1994

PARA.TAB: This bill contains three sets of amendments to legislation in the industrial relations portfolio. First, the bill alters the arrangements for industrial relations in the coal industry. Secondly, it gives effect to a recommendation of the Remuneration Tribunal that the parliamentary allowance be incorporated into the base salaries of members of parliament. Thirdly, the bill improves the quorum and voting requirements for the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill represents a landmark step in the rationalisation of industrial relations arrangements in the Australian coal mining industry.

The bill provides for amendments to the Coal Industry Act 1946 and the Industrial Relations Act 1988. It will bring industrial relations arrangements in the coal industry into the industrial relations mainstream. From the day it comes into effect, industrial relations in that industry will be regulated by the provisions of the Industrial Relations Act 1988.

The coal industry tribunal's powers and functions are presently established by complementary Commonwealth and New South Wales legislation, which commenced in 1946. That makes the coal industry tribunal about the same age as the Liberal Party. Some might say that they are equally anachronistic in the 1990s. Fortunately coal industry unions and employers have proven themselves willing to embrace reform.

We have been able to implement the reform in a manner acceptable to both unions and employers, to whom I want to pay tribute. Without them this historic change could not have been undertaken in an industrially peaceful manner.

Only through detailed negotiations have we have been able to reach agreement with the united mine workers on most aspects of the legislation. Where we have been unable to agree, such as on the issue of access to enterprise flexibility agreements, we have agreed to disagree. In practice the government wouldn't expect this to become a major issue in the industry, given the high level of unionism and the strong leadership of the UMW. Either way, the experience of this legislation gives us cause for optimism that future issues can be addressed in a similarly cooperative, tripartite fashion.

This has been the way so many of the government's reforms have been achieved in the last decade. And in the coal industry, like so many others, the conservatives left it to Labor to reform the special industrial arrangements that applied, arrangements introduced in 1946 to meet the specific circumstances then applying in New South Wales, and arrangements that are no longer appropriate to a modern and export-focused industry. Particularly when that industry is now as significant in queensland as it is in New South Wales.

The current complementary legislation reflects an agreement between the two governments—Commonwealth and New South Wales—for the regulation of the coal industry in New South Wales. Each of the two governments has undertaken not to take any action, without the prior concurrence of the other, to repeal or amend any of the legislation covered by the agreement.

The government of New South Wales has indicated to the Commonwealth that it is also their view that industrial regulation of the coal mining industry should be mainstreamed through the transferring of the powers of the coal industry tribunal to the existing Commonwealth and state industrial tribunals.

I wish to emphasise that in view of the existing agreement over changes to the current complementary legislation, the measures proposed in this bill will only commence when the Governor of New South Wales agrees in writing.

The bill is introduced at a time when the coal industry has been going through a period of significant reform to its administrative and industrial relations arrangements. In 1992 this parliament, acting with the benefit of complementary legislation passed by the New South Wales parliament, made changes to the functions of the Joint Coal Board. This included making the Australian industrial registry responsible for administrative support to the coal industry tribunal, in addition to performing that role for the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. Also, during 1992, legislation was passed to establish a new coal mining industry (long service leave funding) corporation to reform the way long service leave was funded and administered in the industry. These reforms are all designed to improve the efficiency of the coal industry.

The role and functions of the coal industry tribunal have of course been the subject of public discussion for many years. A number of previous inquiries have recommended its abolition. However it is only this government, through today's historic legislation, that has bitten the bullet on a necessary reform. It has done so after full consultation and discussion with the relevant industry parties, all of whose views have been taken into account in drafting the legislation.

The process of mainstreaming began in August 1993, when the government wrote to a wide range of industry parties, including the relevant state ministers, seeking their views on the industrial relations arrangements which should apply to the coal industry in the future. We received a range of responses.

We continued the consultation process by releasing, in July 1994, a copy of a draft exposure bill and explanatory material outlining a preferred approach to reform. Again, a range of views were received in response. The government has considered all of those views in developing this legislation.

We consider that the coal industry should be subject to the same industrial relations institutional arrangements as other industries. The coal industry no longer needs a separate, specialised and insular industrial relations system.

This is a fundamental change in a key export industry. We don't deny it will be challenging for the parties to adapt to the mainstream system after such a long period under specialised arrangements, however we are confident they will do so smoothly and effectively.

The bill, when proclaimed, will mean the abolition of the coal industry tribunal and full integration of coal industry industrial relations arrangements with the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.
Awards made by the coal industry tribunal will continue in force as if they were awards of the commission, and matters which had commenced in the tribunal will be heard by the commission.

The bill expressly provides for the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to have regard to any decisions of the coal industry tribunal that are relevant to the matters before the commission. Furthermore we expect that, in accordance with its usual practice when assuming a new jurisdiction, the commission will give due weight to relevant decisions of the local coal authorities and boards of reference established under the coal industry act.

It is appropriate for the legislation to expressly recognise what would be the practice ordinarily adopted by the commission. The considered views of the previous specialised tribunal ought not be ignored when they are relevant to decisions of the commission. The requirement will be for the commission to `have regard to' relevant decisions, not that it be bound by them. As time passes, earlier decisions of the tribunal will cease to be relevant as they are overtaken by changes in circumstances.

Following very constructive discussions which the Commonwealth has had with the New South Wales and Queensland governments, the bill will also establish a basis on which New South Wales and Queensland will be able to legislate to overcome jurisdictional restrictions, which would otherwise confront the Australian Industrial Relations Commission in dealing with local disputes in the coal mining industry.

If New South Wales or Queensland adopts the federal act, with appropriate modifications, to apply as a law of the state concerned, the commission will be able to exercise the powers and perform the functions available to it under that state law.

Reflecting the complementary nature of this scheme, any full bench of the commission which is exercising such jurisdiction is, as far as practicable, to include a cross-appointed member of the state tribunal.
There will be further discussions with those states and the industry parties about the best way to implement these aspects of the legislative scheme.

There is a question of whether New South Wales will be able to change its side of the existing complementary legislation within the same time frame as the Commonwealth. Understandably, the state government wishes to be certain of the final form of the bill after it has been considered by the Australian parliament before proceeding with its own legislation.

To avoid delays, the bill relies on the corporations power for certain transitional purposes. In particular, this relates to the conversion of tribunal awards to commission awards. However, reliance on that constitutional power will cease when complementary New South Wales legislation is in force. I should also mention that the bill's reliance on the trade and commerce power to supplement the commission's jurisdiction will not be necessary since the Commonwealth and state governments are developing a complementary scheme for this industry. In those circumstances, it will be unnecessary to proclaim that provision.

The bill provides that the legislation will have effect from a date to be fixed by proclamation. We intend that the bill come into force on 1 July 1995, subject to the agreement of the Governor of New South Wales, as required by the bill. This will allow the commission and the parties enough time to make all appropriate arrangements before the legislation commences.

The proposed amendments to the Remuneration and Allowances Act 1990 will implement a recommendation by the remuneration tribunal that the parliamentary allowance of $4,767 per annum, introduced from 1 july 1994, be incorporated into the base salary of senators and members of the House of Representatives.
The tribunal said that an amendment to the legislation would serve to improve the transparency of parliamentarians' remuneration.

By way of background to the proposed amendments, the annual base salary of parliamentarians is currently specified in the legislation, and is payable at the maximum salary rate applicable to a senior executive service band 1 officer in the Australian Public Service. This pay linkage provided a practical and sustainable approach to determining salaries of the members of parliament and senators, and ensured that they would not be treated in isolation. However, with the introduction of performance-based pay for the SES, the link originally intended has not been maintained.

The parliamentary allowance re-established the pay linkage between parliamentarians and the ses at the base of SES band 2. The tribunal, when it determined this allowance, had regard to wage fixing principles of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, the spread of enterprise bargaining agreements in the public sector and in the general workforce, as well as developments in parliamentary practice and the conditions under which parliamentary service is performed.
It should be noted that this measure does not affect the net remuneration of members of parliament.

LIFE INSURANCE BILL 1994
The Life Insurance Bill 1994 introduces a modern regulatory framework for the life insurance industry.
It represents the first major reform of the life insurance law since the then Treasurer, Ben Chifley introduced the Life Insurance Act 1945. That act will be superseded by this bill.

Today, as in 1945, the life insurance industry makes a significant economic and social contribution to Australia. Thousands of households and businesses rely on savings and risk products sold by life companies. The life industry has assets over $115 billion and plays a key role in our financial system. It also makes an important contribution to raising and managing our national savings.

However, the life industry operates in an environment which is considerably different from conditions prevailing in 1945. There have been remarkable technological developments; financial deregulation; advances in actuarial and accounting methods and innovation in life product design.
That is why we need a completely new regulatory regime.

The Life Insurance Bill 1994 will result in a clearer, stronger and more modern regulatory regime which substantially strengthens prudential controls. It aims to protect policy owners within the framework of a well managed, competitive and financially sound life insurance industry.
The measures proposed in this bill will make the industry more accountable to consumers, the financial community and the industry regulator, the Insurance and Superannuation Commission.
The bill ensures that life companies themselves will take a more active and responsible role in supervising their activities and operations.
Directors, auditors and actuaries of life companies will have increased responsibilities.

Directors will be required to ensure that the life company gives priority to policy owner interests when dealing with statutory fund assets. They will also be required to form an audit committee to monitor financial reporting, internal management and financial controls.
The Insurance and Superannuation Commission will be given clear supervisory powers over products developed during the past decade as well as new products developed in the future.

Life companies will be required to meet upgraded solvency and capital adequacy standards demonstrating that they are financially sound, able to meet their existing obligations, and are in a position to continue as a going concern.
Life Insurance Actuarial Standards Board will be established to develop these and other actuarial standards relevant to life company prudential controls.
More comprehensive and meaningful financial statements will make each life company's solvency position and underlying performance more transparent and capable of comparison.
To more effectively supervise the life insurance industry, the Insurance and Superannuation Commission will be given additional powers and resources to:
issue legally enforceable Rules to life companies covering financial reporting and other matters;
investigate life companies and obtain statistical, financial and asset information from them; and to
initiate judicial management processes in the event of fraud or where the financial viability of a life company is at stake.

The government recognises that the new regulatory framework will bring some changes to the operations of life companies, and consequently has developed the framework in consultation with the industry. A number of technical requirements have already been made to the bill as a result of ongoing consultation.
The government originally signalled that consumer measures would form part of the package for the new life insurance regulatory regime.
Substantial progress has already been made towards the government's goals of improving information disclosure to policy owners and introducing a code of practice.

To establish the best form of disclosure, the ISC has engaged an independent consultant to interview stakeholders, conduct focus groups and run quantitative tests involving 1,200 consumers. The consultant's report is due shortly, and the new disclosure rules should be finalised in early 1995.
Work on the code of practice for life companies is also well under way. The government taskforce developing the code is currently considering 70 submissions made on a draft code released last August.

The government has also invited the Life Insurance Federation of Australia to form a working group to develop a framework for an industry based system of accreditation of life agents. The working group will also consider whether any changes to the draft code are desirable when it reports in December.
The draft consumer protection legislation, the disclosure rules and the code will be finalised when these processes are complete.

The government intends to release draft legislation to facilitate these consumer protection initiatives by the end of this year. This will provide time for public comment prior to introducing the legislation as a separate bill in the Autumn 1995 session of parliament.

In closing, I would like to thank all the people who contributed to developing the new regulatory regime particularly Bob Glading of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. Mr Glading's dedication over a five year period has resulted in a world class system of supervising life companies.

The measures contained in the bill to promote policy owners protection and a more efficient life insurance industry will result in additional supervisory costs being incurred by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission.
These additional resources have been estimated at $1.269 million in 1994-95, $1.053 million in 1995-96, and $1.053 million in 1996-97.
These costs will be fully recouped through an increase in the ISC annual levy on life insurance companies. This levy was increased from $28,000 to $70,000 per company from 1 October 1994.
I commend the bill to the House.
LIFE INSURANCE (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS AND REPEALS) BILL 1994
The Life Insurance (Consequential Amendments and Repeals) Bill 1994 together with the Life Insurance Bill 1994 will give effect to a new modern regulatory framework for the life insurance industry.
This bill repeals the Life Insurance Act 1945, and makes consequential amendments to the Corporations Law and other Acts.
Financial Implications
The measures contained in this bill are consequential upon the measures proposed in the Life Insurance Bill 1994 and will not directly incur any costs.
I commend the Life Insurance (Consequential Amendments and Repeals) Bill 1994 to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to this bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

The purpose of this bill is to effect the repeal of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (Financial Support Fund) Act 1976, that authorised the ratification by Australia of the agreement to establish a financial support fund among OECD members.

SPEECH.PARA: The fund was designed to assist OECD members facing serious external account difficulties following the oil price crisis of 1973-74 and was intended to supplement, on a last resource basis, other sources of credit to which members encountering serious difficulties have had recourse.

When proposed to parliament, the government saw the main value of the fund in terms of its capacity to help maintain healthy trading and financial relationships between the major countries, encouraging and assisting members to avoid unilateral trading restrictions. The bill was debated by parliament on 6 May 1976 and the corresponding Act received Royal Assent on 25 August 1976. However, the corresponding legislation was not proclaimed.

The fund was never brought into effect, because of the failure of some other OECD countries (most notably the United States and France) to ratify the agreement. In the meantime, the world economy has already been exposed—and adjusted—to two major oil price shocks, the first one, which gave origin to this legislation, when the average crude price for petroleum more than trebled, from $US 3.14 per barrel in 1973 to $US 11.22 per barrel in 1974, and the second one, in the late seventies, when it rose from $US 12.95 per barrel in 1978 to $US 35.48 per barrel in 1980. With petroleum prices now fluctuating in the range of $US 16-17 per barrel (equivalent to around 5 $US per barrel in 1973 prices) we are now a long way back from the sense of emergency of the early seventies.
As the need for the fund has now ceased the legislation should be repealed.
I present the explanatory memorandum for the bill and commend this bill to the Senate.
