TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Community Affairs References Committee on matters pertaining to the marketing of the disability reform package, together with the transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to refer to the marketing of the disability reform package because it is a textbook case of what not to do with a consultancy. I believe that this report will serve as a benchmark in matters pertaining to the marketing of any package in the future. On 8 February 1994 the Senate referred the marketing of the disability reform package to the committee. The matter came to the attention of the Senate when questions were asked about irregularities in the letting of a $4.95 million consultancy project to market the reforms introduced by the Social Security (Disability and Sickness Support) Act 1991.

PARA.TAB: I would like to acknowledge the significant contribution made by Senator Patterson, who first raised this matter and pursued it vigorously through several estimates hearings, finally having the matter referred to the then Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs. Senator Patterson has led the way in identifying a number of serious problems in government departments, particularly in the selection and management of consultancies. Her efforts in this inquiry have led to the development of recommendations which should have a substantial effect on the way in which departments should operate in the future.

It is also important to note that this inquiry effectively began through the estimates process. While it is clear that much of the evidence obtained by the committee would not have been available in a public hearing, nonetheless the investigation that Senator Patterson initiated demonstrates that estimates committees are an important monitoring and accountability mechanism. When properly used, they can help to identify systemic problems which need to be addressed by widespread reforms.

The new legislation, which came into effect on 12 November 1991, brought sweeping changes to a broad range of disability pensions, payments and schemes to increase training and rehabilitation. The reforms further emphasised the shift in attitude away from people with disabilities being able to work in sheltered workshops. The legislation clearly encouraged people with disabilities to take up work in positions in the general community where that was possible and proposed measures that would help in this transition.

In order for the disability reforms to be successful, the attitudes of employers, employees, doctors, health workers, people with disabilities and their parents and carers needed to be changed. They needed to be informed to accept that changes were possible and that support and advice would be available to help in making the transition where that was applicable. The reforms also included changes to support pensions, thereby giving rise to a need to give assurances to parents, carers and people with disabilities that they would still receive their financial assistance under the various programs.

The reforms cut across the policy and program responsibilities of three different departments: the Department of Social Security, what is now the Department of Human Services and Health and the Department of Employment, Education and Training. These three departments were provided with substantial funding to publicise the changes in disability service, employment opportunities and income support. In 1991 the departments decided to let a $4.95 million consultancy project to market the reforms Australia-wide. I regret to say, on behalf of taxpayers, that it proved to be a gross waste of taxpayers' money.

The committee found the disability reform marketing project was fraught with problems from the outset. It seems everything that could go wrong with the consultancy went wrong. It was a great demonstration of Murphy's law. Most importantly, the company contracted to perform the majority of the task, Corporate Impacts Pty Ltd, went into liquidation before the project was finished.

The committee's terms of references were to examine and report on, first, the circumstances surrounding the letting of the contracts to market the disability reform package; second, the management of the contracts to market the disability reform package by the management committee and its subcommittees; third, the nature and extent of debts owed to creditors that relate directly or indirectly to contracts to market the disability reform package; fourth, the extent to which the Commonwealth may have been mischarged by companies contracted to market the disability reform package; and fifth, the reasons why advice from two or three departments on the management committee to terminate a contract to market the DRP was not heeded.

The committee was also to examine and report on the circumstances surrounding the letting of a further contract in April 1993 to a company that was contracted to market the DRP although it must have been suspected that the company was in financial difficulty; the doubts expressed during Senate estimates about the objectivity of the liquidator appointed to a company that was contracted to market the DRP; the extent to which the strategy that was adopted to market the DRP effectively met its objectives; and, finally, the adequacy of current guidelines and practices for the letting and management of contracts in the circumstances of the marketing of the DRP.

The committee has considered evidence gathered in the course of public and in camera hearings and from submissions from interested parties. The Senate committee met with representatives of the various departments responsible for the disability reform project and with representatives from Corporate Impacts. Unfortunately, the senate committee could not hear evidence from Mr Michael Ward, who was a co-principal of Corporate Impacts Pty Ltd for much of the project, because we understand that he left the country in late 1993.

A large proportion of the hearings and evidence provided to this committee was in camera. It would have been impossible to have produced a coherent report without reference to it. However, the committee took particular care to use only that information which it considered was not detrimental to individuals, companies or departments.

The committee believes that the expenditure of public funds by departments is a role which requires prudent and efficient management. The evidence relating in this case to the expenditure of nearly $5 million in public funds by the Departments of Social Security, Employment, Education and Training, and Human Services and Health, and the Office of Government Information and Advertising is of very grave concern.

The committee has concluded that the selection of Corporate Impacts Pty Ltd emanated from a dubious selection process undertaken by the Office of Government Information and Advertising. The project was not advertised. Rather, OGIA used its own limited database from which to select this company. Corporate Impacts, along with several well known companies, was recommended to the Ministerial Committee on Government Information and Advertising as suitable. Eventually, Corporate Impacts was chosen over the others because of its unique proposal to use network marketing rather than traditional media to get the message about disability reform across. The committee found that the process through which departments recommended Corporate Impacts to ministers for approval was severely flawed and not in keeping with the existing commonwealth procurement guidelines.

The contract for the marketing of the disability reform package was signed on 29 August 1991. From the evidence provided to the committee, it seems the contract was signed only after a drawn out process of negotiation and then only reluctantly by both parties because its provisions satisfied neither. The committee has concluded that the contract itself was poorly drafted and the negotiations associated with it were misleading and ill-advised.

The successful company, Corporate Impacts Pty Ltd, was a relatively small, underresourced company whose two principals claimed to have experience in network marketing and working with government. It received a payment of $25,000 in public funds from OGIA even before the contract was signed. Apparently the funds were to enable it to carry on preliminary work. Extraordinarily, it also received a payment of $412,500 upon signing the contract—again apparently to cover work already commenced.

The committee found that the management of the project was particularly ineffective. The departments established an incredibly cumbersome and bureaucratic committee system to administer the project, ignoring a specific ministerial direction to appoint a single project director. The relations between the parties to the project were strained if not openly hostile. The payment and acquittal process adopted was particularly troublesome and the departments continually called for changes in the process and held up payments to the contractor. The departments failed to recognise and act upon the early warning signs of Corporate Impacts' liquidity problems and, as a result, the company went into voluntary liquidation in May 1993, leaving considerable debts unpaid.

The committee has been informed that the full list of creditors numbers some 230. A total of $124,855 is listed as owing to partly secured creditors. The remaining creditors are unsecured and are owed debts ranging from $500,000, allegedly owed to Ms Anne Gorman, a former principal of the company, to amounts of $10 and $50. Mr Michael Ward, a former co-principal, is suing Corporate Impacts for $164,403.50 for wrongful dismissal. A company owned by Mr Ward and another former associate of Corporate Impacts, Mr Terry Borella, is also claiming damages from Corporate Impacts of $1,879,150. Many of the unsecured creditors are from small country towns such as Innisfail in North Queensland and Katherine in the Northern Territory. The damage done to the credibility of the disability programs involved in this project would be considerable.

Over $600,000 in quantifiable costs was expended by the departments in administering this project—in other words, over 10 per cent of its value. The committee believes that the disability reform marketing project achieved only very patchy positive outcomes and only in relation to people with disabilities and their carers. The committee doubts if anything was achieved in the wider community at all. With respect to the further contract let to Corporate Impacts by the Environment Protection Agency, the committee considers that the EPA failed in its duty to protect the Commonwealth's interests by not investigating the company's background and financial status.

The committee has made a number of recommendations in the light of its investigation of these two consultancies. The committee particularly addressed the need for changes to the Commonwealth procurement guidelines to strengthen and clarify them. Further, the committee recommends changes in relation to the drafting of contracts to protect the Commonwealth's interests, and greater responsiveness, cooperation and involvement on the part of the Attorney-General's Department, including an examination of the contractual process.

The committee recommends measures to ensure that companies are accountable for claims made in tendering for projects in relation to their resources, staffing levels and experience. Recommendations are also made that departments train their staff in proper record keeping and the legal ramifications of contracting consultancy services.

Finally, the committee recommends that the government response to this report specifically identifies all moneys considered to have been wrongly paid and that ministers of the relevant departments, including the Department of Administrative Services and the Office of Government Information and Advertising, clearly state the extent to which each of these departments failed to meet their responsibilities and the steps undertaken to correct this.

In conclusion, the committee wishes to thank those individuals and organisations who made submissions and gave evidence at public hearings. I think this inquiry has thrown up a report that should be mandatory reading for those who wish to engage in the letting of contracts on behalf of the government and the taxpayer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report of the Community Affairs References Committee on matters pertaining to the marketing of the disability reform package is testimony to what I can only describe as a disgrace and a debacle, and the use of taxpayers' money with no real or apparent concern from many of the people involved, including the officers and, I have to say, also the ministers. It was a contract that was let, as Senator Herron has said, across three departments—DEET, the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services, as it was then known, and the Department of Social Security—and, within DAS, the Office of Government Information and Advertising. Therein lies part of the story, which I will explain further down the track.

PARA.TAB: In 1991 I expressed concern in Senate estimates hearings about the letting of the contract and also the progress of it. In 1991, 1992 and 1993 I asked question after question, and there were ministers sitting at the table when I asked those questions. Senator Richardson and Senator McMullan, who was not a minister at the time but who was there representing the minister as a parliamentary secretary, heard my questions. Minister after minister heard my questions and not one minister, it appears, inquired into the progress of that tender and the contract. We saw $5 million plus of taxpayers' money wasted down the gurgler. The goal that that contract was supposed to achieve—that is, the marketing of the disability reform package—was not achieved and that money did not go to do the job that it was supposed to do.

That $4.95 million contract was let to a company called Corporate Impacts to market the disability reform package in August 1991. Both of the principals of that company had worked in the Public Service. We read about one of them in the Australian Financial Review in 1983, where it stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a new private specialist consultancy service has been established to interpret the Australian Labor Party and its policies to local and international business.
Ms Gorman, who had set herself up as a company, said:
We want to act as a bridge between business and government, rather than as a lobbyist.

Mr Ward, who was one of the principals working in that company, had also worked in the Public Service and they purported to know how the Public Service worked. In fact, Ms Gorman wrote articles telling people how to negotiate with the government. We saw an absolute disaster when she actually set about doing it herself for a contract that I believe, and I think the committee believes, was far too large for the resources that that company had.

PARA.TAB: The departments involved in this project were DAS, OGIA, DEET, the Department of Human Services and Health and the Department of Social Security. It is estimated that these departments spent an additional $600,000 administering the project. So we not only have $4.95 million and a couple of other million, $1.5 million or $2 million, going to other companies that were also involved in the project, but we also have $600,000 of administrative costs on behalf of these departments.

We can see how many meetings the departments had. In May to June of 1992, I think the departments had eight meetings discussing the project. I have to say that the people on the committee, who had to painstakingly go through the many pages of estimates and the many pages of evidence that we were given, deserve credit for producing a document on which we could all agree, which outlined step-by-step this debacle. What we uncovered at each stage was just gross mismanagement.

First of all, I questioned the circumstances surrounding the letting of the contract. As Senator Herron said, the project was not advertised—as honourable senators would expect under the Commonwealth's own procurement guidelines. A contract for $4.95 million should have been. Originally, the names of five prominent advertising agencies were put before the ministerial committee on government information and advertising, and the ministerial committee thought an alternative approach, other than the traditional advertising one, should be considered. I think Senator McMullan apparently said that what the committee wanted was `a new, fresh point of reference'—whatever that was supposed to mean.

OGIA did not attempt to advertise the new approach or seek major experienced marketing firms—I think what the ministerial committee was complaining about was that it had approached advertising companies. So an officer of OGIA interrogated OGIA's database, which was totally inadequate—1,500 names of potential contractors—and came up with three names, two of which were too small and were not considered and one name which was recommended to the ministerial committee.

This is a couple of years ago now. I have files that stretch right across my office in Melbourne on this issue. One of my staff members rang the agencies and asked them whether they had been adequately informed about the shift from a traditional advertising approach to this network marketing or marketing approach or new reference point or whatever language we like to use. They said no, they had not. One of them told me that had it known there was a change in emphasis it would have withdrawn its tender, because that was not its style or its modus operandi.

It transpired, virtually, that it was almost impossible for Corporate Impacts not to get the contract because all the others put in an advertising approach. In fact, when I looked at the letter that was sent to the advertising agencies and then at the contract, I found that it really was not clear that anything other than an advertising approach was wanted. The advertising agencies were asked for television shots. They were asked for radio blurbs that they might use—I have forgotten the terminology that one might use for this—but it was very much an advertising approach.

When it transpired that Corporate Impacts was most probably the only company that was going to get this job, did OGIA bother to check up on the company? No. It made a few cursory phone calls around to other government agencies for which Corporate Impacts had undertaken some contracts—I think one of the contracts was for $150,000. The committee was told that if Corporate Impacts did a contract for $150,000 and it was okay, the company would be able to do one for $4.95 million. What baloney! What a disaster! If a company can undertake and achieve something on a $150,000 contract, is it therefore capable of doing one for $4.95 million?

I then went to the ASC and asked it for the last return that Corporate Impacts had lodged prior to the letting of the contract. What do we find? We find that Corporate Impacts has more debts than it has assets. When I sought advice from an accountant, who happened to be my father—our resources are a bit limited in this game—he said to me, `If I were a bank manager, I would not lend them money.' We are giving them a contract for $4.95 million of taxpayers' money. The company was not in a position to undertake the contract. Nobody in any of the departments nor any minister felt a responsibility for the fact that this company was given a contract when it was not capable of actually undertaking it. No checks were made. A Dun and Bradstreet check was not done. It was an absolute disgrace. At no time did OGIA really attempt to investigate the bona fides of the company.

I questioned officers at length in estimates and during the inquiry to determine why no investigation was undertaken and who accepted responsibility. Guess what? The officers gave me no reasons and the responsibility was really nobody's because there was a management committee with a chairman. I stand to be corrected, but I think one officer said to me at one point, `Well, I was a chairman, but I didn't have voting rights' or `I wasn't in a position to vote.' We had a chairman who did not really know what his role was. We had members from the three managing departments and those staff changed. Really, nobody was responsible. The blame could not be sheeted home to anybody and that is a great criticism of this whole matter.

The departments responsible for the contract set up a committee that I described at one point in estimates as a camel. It was a bureaucratic nightmare. There were changes in staff membership and a lack of clarity about authority and lines of responsibilities. In fact, the committee was like an amoeba: it changed. At one point it involved people on Corporate Impacts and then it decided that was not very good and it would have meetings without Corporate Impacts. So it was very difficult for us to really define what the management committee was.In addition, a project manager was supposed to be appointed and the ministerial advisory committee said that a project manager should be appointed. We never got a decent answer as to why a project manager was not appointed. Nobody could answer that. The buck did not stop there either.

The other thing that absolutely astounded me was, as I discovered in estimates, that the Commonwealth had paid Corporate Impacts $25,000 prior to the contract even being signed. I believe this to be totally inappropriate. So Corporate Impacts had $25,000. I asked what would happen if the contract had not been signed. One officer told me, `Well, senator, we would have had to take measures to get the money back.'

If it had been that officer's $25,000 worth of superannuation, I wonder whether he would have been so generous with it. If he were building a house, would he have decided to give the builder $25,000 before the contract was signed because the builder needed to buy a bit of equipment? The answer is no. But he did it with the taxpayers' money. With the taxpayers' money, $25,000 was paid before the contract was signed. I had some stairs built at the back of my house. I would not have done that, but it is my money. What every officer of the Commonwealth and every member of this parliament ought to know is that the money that they spend is not their money. It is the money of the citizens of Australia.

As I said, I raised this matter in the estimates in 1991, 1992 and 1993 and there was no real action on the part of the departments involved or the ministers responsible for these departments until Corporate Impacts announced its voluntary liquidation. I asked questions in estimates ad nauseam about what I thought were extraordinarily high head hour charges being made by the principals of the company. We were told that if it is a very short contract, often there are very high head hours in advertising and marketing but that usually a company, if it has a contract over a longer period, will offer a discount for head hours because it is not starting on a new contract or a new job and for all sorts of other reasons. But there was no attempt, it appears, to negotiate down those head hours. I believe the departments could have negotiated a lower fee for a contract of this length and size.

The departments of Human Services and Health and Social Security sought to terminate the contract as early as 1991. I was advised in estimates that during the period May to June there were innumerable meetings—from memory I think about eight, but I cannot be certain of that—over a period of about five weeks, which discussed the termination of the contract. It transpired that DEET was opposed to such action.

When I watched the people answering the questions during the estimates process, I felt that they did not look comfortable. When people are skating on the circumference of the truth and trying not to tell people exactly what they want to know, one can often tell that that is the case. I was very interested to know why DEET as a department wanted to keep the contract going.

When I asked why the contract was not terminated and when two of the three departments—including the Department of Social Security, which was paying the most money—wanted to terminate it, I was told, `Oh, Senator, we needed a consensus'. Imagine what would happen if I, as a director of a company, were to go the shareholders and say, `We have made a $5 million bungle. We realised fairly early down the track that it was a bit of a disaster, but there were three people on the committee and another one who did not know whether or not he had a vote. We could not get a consensus between the three that were supposed to vote, and only two said that we should terminate it, so we did not do so.' We all know what the shareholders would say: `It's time you found another job. We don't need you as a director of our company.' I am sure that Senator Gibson, with his business experience, would agree with me that that is exactly what the shareholders would say. The view was, `We haven't a consensus, so we will go ambling down the track with this contract that appears to be a failure. We will keep spending taxpayers' money in this way because we have not got consensus.'

Let me tell senators why there was not consensus. It was at this point of time that a Mr Sid Hickman came into it. I suggested at one point, when I was becoming a little weary of the whole thing, that we could write a soapie called `The Contract'—for a whole lot of other reasons that I will not bring up in the chamber at present. Mr Sid Hickman appeared on the scene who, it transpires, had been employed by Corporate Impacts. He appears to have lobbied, I do not know who, but officers said it was not the officers. I presume it could have been Minister Beazley, who was then the minister for education. But for some unknown reason DEET was not going along with the termination of the contract.

I remind honourable senators that Mr Hickman used to work for Mr Beazley, then he worked for Dr Carmen Lawrence, and after that for Corporate Impacts. I do not know what else he did in between but he eventually went back to Mr Beazley. I think it is inappropriate that DEET would not agree to the termination of the contract. I do not believe the evidence given by the department in the estimates hearings warranted the strength of its response in saying that the contract should not be terminated. The other two departments really had no other option.

From the beginning to the end, the letting of this contract was a disgrace and a debacle. Satisfactory answers have not been given to explain, for example, that while the contract stipulated that Corporate Impacts be paid on a monthly basis—that is $200,000 per month—all except $62,000 of the $4.95 million designated for the contract had been paid to Corporate Impacts by February 1993, even though the contract was not to end until July 1993. What they intended to do from February to July is beyond my comprehension. So all but $62,000 of the contract was paid out.

During the course of the project relations between the departments and Corporate Impacts apparently became quite bad. It was decided to water down the minutes of the meetings to make them records of decisions. That is what was being done by this camel of a committee; it was its attempt to improve things.

Corporate Impacts also had poor accounting procedures and acquittals and that became a major source of contention with the project during the two years 1991-93. The fault most probably lies in both camps, with the departments not knowing what they wanted or needed, and the company being under-resourced to carry out the project.

It was astonishing that such relations and such poor acquittal procedures emanated from Corporate Impacts when both its principals, Ms Anne Gorman and Mr Michael Ward—and the committee was unhappy that Mr Ward was not available to answer questions that the committee wished to put to him—claimed to have extensive experience in working with government. The committee felt so strongly about this that it has recommended that consultants who cannot deliver the product or who provide false and misleading information about their skills be prevented from tendering for any Commonwealth work for five years. It is astonishing that Mr Ward is not around to face the music, having left the country in late 1993.

Another part of the whole saga is that Mr Ward is suing Corporate Impacts for $164,403.50 for wrongful dismissal. Another of his companies, of which Mr Terry Borella appears to be a co-director and was so far as the ASC was concerned until a couple of weeks ago, Yardmont Pty Ltd, is suing Corporate Impacts to the tune of $1,879,150. Ms Gorman is seeking $500,000 from her own company; the tax man wants $64,000 in unpaid group tax. Former staff are owed $52,814 in superannuation, and there is a claim in for $18,276 in other expenses. There is unlikely to be much left. Also the office told us that there were `deliverables' that had not been delivered to the Commonwealth. Unsecured creditors across Australia, some of whom gave evidence to the committee in a public hearing, are likely to receive nothing.

Some of them are very small groups representing people with disabilities. Some people told us how their group's creditability in the community had taken a battering because they had put on a function and were not paid. Other people were asked to provide catering, printing and other services and were left with the bill. It is hardly a good way to advertise a disability reform package, especially when departments were paying Corporate Impacts in advance.

One should ask: where did the money go and did anybody benefit from a windfall? I will tell honourable senators who did not benefit, and that was people with disabilities and taxpayers. They are the two lots of people that we should be most concerned about in this chamber. After all, the project was supposed to centre on people with disabilities.

The Senate committee was informed that over $600,000 was spent on quantifiable administration costs by departments for the package. Also, one has to budget in the cost to the Senate of the inquiry—namely, the costs of staff, the travel, and the time we as senators have spent and the staff time that has been expended on this inquiry.

It is interesting to note that the formal post project evaluations of the package found that most people found out about the reforms from the traditional departmental networks. The target groups were doctors, employers, people with disabilities, carers who were to be told about the government's program in increasing the employment of people with disabilities in open employment, or increasing the opportunities so to do. They did not find out as a result of the expenditure of $4.95 million of taxpayers' money. Instead, they found out from the traditional networks of departments through the disabilities sector. They were the people who alerted me to the fact that there was a problem. They kept on saying, `Money is being given out and we in the disability sector are not hearing about it.'

The committee has recommended that the ministers of relevant departments, including DAS and OGIA, clearly state the extent to which each of their departments failed to meet their responsibilities and the specific steps they intend to take to correct this. As Senator Herron said, this report should be a prescribed text book for all students in public policy. The Senate estimates hearings should be prescribed reading too because they tell the story behind this report.
I have to read to the Senate a quote that Ms Anne Gorman, the author of a report on management consultants entitled The secret army, made in about September 1989. There is irony in it:

SPEECH.PARA: There is often a niggling feeling that you pay out all this money and there is nothing concrete to show for it.

She was talking about consultancies. Is that not ironic? One pays out all this money and there is nothing to show for it. We have paid out $4.95 million and there is nothing to show for it. Perhaps it shows that this is a debacle and a disgrace and that people with disabilities have been left carrying the can. As I said, this ought to be a prescribed textbook on how not to manage a contract and how not to spend taxpayers' money.

TAB.TAB: (a)the commercial rental arrangement is entered into in the course of a business conducted by a person who has purchased the video game cartridge (`the rental video game owner'); and

These amendments are directed towards the issue of video game rentals. We are moving to delete new subsection 31(4), which exempts video game cartridges from the exclusive rental right provisions. Unlike the case of CDs, where there was some doubt whether they were valid under the provisions of GATT—although we feel that the government should have taken the course of action to challenge the provisions and accept the amendments that the Democrats moved—this one is a much clearer case. It is very obvious that they are valid under GATT.

PARA.TAB: Video game cartridges are not copyable. There is a South African court ruling that they are in the nature of cinematographic works. Non-copyable cinematographic works are specifically excluded from the exclusive rental rights provisions of the TRIPS agreement. In addition, both the United States and Canada have legislation which excludes video game cartridges from the exclusive rental rights provisions of copyright law.

At the same time, we are moving to introduce a system whereby video game cartridge rental operators will be forced to pay a one-off up-front royalty fee for the right to rent out the cartridge. By moving for the deletion of proposed new subsection 31(4)—this is in clause 4(b) of the current bill—we effectively exclude non-copyable computer programs, including video game cartridges.

New subsection 31(3) exempts from the exclusive rental right `a machine or device in which a computer program is embodied if the program is not able to be copied in the course of the ordinary use of the machine or device'. This is obviously aimed at situations like computer programs that control car engines. Obviously we do not want to have to get the permission of the copyright owner for the program in order to rent a car.

New subsection 31(4) then makes it clear that 31(3) is not intended to apply to devices that are usually used to store computer programs such as floppy discs, cartridges, CD-ROMs, integrated circuits and so on. By deleting subsection 31(4), programs stored on these devices are excluded from the exclusive rental rights so long as they are not copyable.

The rest of the amendment describes a mechanism based on a compulsory 10 per cent up-front premium paid by rental operators when they buy the video cartridge. In return, they get a sticker for the video cartridge which states that it is authorised for rental use.

I trust that the minister will be able to respond to the questions that are raised by these amendments, because I feel the government would have a hard time to justify opposing an amendment that does a number of things. First of all, it ensures a reward to copyright holders. This is an issue that we are very concerned about. In the CD issue the government ensured that but it lost the other two, because our amendments will also provide consumer access to a rental market. In the case of CDs, the government lost that. Thirdly, it will provide protection for the interest of legitimate existing businesses.

As I have already said, the provisions are legal under TRIPS, so why on earth would the government oppose these amendments? Why would the government not accept them? It is very clear, it seems to me, that we have taken every precaution to ensure that we cannot be attacked by those who think that GATT must be observed to the nth degree. The other substantive reasons stand on their own.

Let me run again through the reasons why it is TRIPS-consistent. TRIPS exempts non-copyable cinematographic work from the exclusive rental right. Video game cartridges are non-copyable. Video games have been ruled by South African courts to be in the nature of cinematographic work. The United States and Canada both currently exempt video game cartridges from such legislation.

Therefore, we argue that video games can be exempted and obviously should be exempted from the exclusive right. There are something like 200,000-plus consumers involved in video game rentals. Many of these video games are educational. Video games cost 20 to 30 times as much to buy as to rent. The market is dominated by two main players, Sega and Nintendo, who would have the market power to end the video game rental market at the stroke of a pen, and I am sure they will.

I think the argument for the government's support on this is overwhelming. But let me not forget the coalition parties. We have an issue here where it is TRIPS-consistent, where video games are educational, where the cost to buy video games is beyond the reach of many people that would like to enjoy them or have derived from them some educational benefit. The copyright holders are being compensated. So why on earth would the coalition parties not support the amendment? I commend my amendments 3 and 4 to the committee.

This amendment is designed to give some recourse to the actual artists—the musicians, programmers and creators—in situations where massive profits are made by record companies, software companies, film companies, and so on, without their passing on the benefits to those artists to any substantial extent. The amendment would create a provision through which the artists could challenge the companies that dominate production and marketing. The plaintive letters from ARIA and other bodies are concerned particularly with these issues. If we make the ability of the corporations and companies who co-own the intellectual property stronger without increasing the ability of the creators of that property, the outcome is obvious.

PARA.TAB: The industry is full of stories of people who have been paid a minor fee for work from which a company has made millions. This is not fair and it is certainly not the intention of copyright to allow companies to exploit artists. The amendment would create a provision which would allow a challenge to be mounted against a big company when that company uses its dominance and monopoly power to effectively charge massive profits and set prices at levels not related to the actual cost of production and marketing. Anyone who has ever looked at pirated goods in Asia would know that if those people can charge the prices that they do, it is certainly the case that the cost to big companies of production, distribution and marketing does not explain the prices we see in Australia.

The situation can only be described as the making of super profits by these big companies through monopoly power. We are trying to create some redress for the situation, and we are doing it in light of the intention to extend copyright powers in various ways. It is important that we act to ensure that copyright is more than a licence for big corporations to print money.

I refer to a conversation I had yesterday with a journalist who said, `What are you talking about? In terms of copyright there will not be any real changes for the rights of those people who create work.' I link that in my mind to the fact that we have had innumerable debates in this chamber about the rights of sovereignty and the ability of the Commonwealth government, as established under High Court rulings, to make decisions in regard to treaties.

I said to a person the other day that the government certainly has these powers but that does not mean that we, as the parliament, cannot be allowed to look at these interests of sovereignty. It was explained that there has never been an instance where the most powerful in an operation, especially in the case of government, gives up that power. Therefore, it can well be argued that if in this case we give the corporations and co-owners of intellectual property greater power, there is no doubt in the world that they will not use that power against the creators of that intellectual property. Those people who think they are going to get more benefits from this have another think coming. At some time in the future they will come to us and ask for protection.

I am sad about the situation. But I would like to give this final opportunity to the government to think carefully about the implications of creating greater corporate power at the expense of the people—the musicians, programmers, creators, artists and writers—who actually create the goods that are of value, and do something to make sure that they get some benefit from their work.

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments relate to the way in which a family's eligibility for family payments is determined. Under the current system the family payment income test is based on taxable income for the previous year. I understand that this system is used primarily because of its administrative simplicity and its ease of understanding. It means that people can assess whether or not they are likely to be eligible simply by reference to their last tax assessment notice.

PARA.TAB: There are, however, a couple of circumstances in which a person can ask the department to have another look at their financial situation. One of those situations is where the family's income is likely to change by more than 25 per cent since last year. This could happen where, for example, a woman gives up her work to have a child.

What concerns me—and I have received representations on this—is that a family could have a substantial drop in income, say, 20 per cent, taking them below the income test threshold, but still remain ineligible for the family payment. They accept the administrative benefits of the department setting a certain percentage drop in income, but it seems to me that 25 per cent may be just too high a level. These amendments will lower that 25 per cent to 15 per cent.

As a consequence, if a family's income drops by 15 per cent or more, taking it under the family payment threshold, it will become eligible for a payment. I know that Senator Newman has raised this issue in the Senate previously and I pay tribute to her for doing so. I hope that my amendments will have the support of both opposition and government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats have put forward a series of 13 amendments to this bill and we will be opposing all of them. Democrat amendments 1 to 3 inclusive seek to reduce the income threshold for family payments from 25 per cent to 15 per cent. Families could have their situations reassessed by the department in relation to the family payment income test if their taxable income for a particular year was to drop by more than 15 per cent rather than 25 per cent compared with the previous year.

PARA.TAB: Although there is something to be said for looking at this threshold with a view to possible reform, the reduction from 25 per cent to 15 per cent will not significantly affect its operation or address the coalition's concerns on the issue.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is not prepared to accept these amendments. First, if we were to change from the 25 per cent to the 15 per cent rule, that would simply shift the ground, margin or boundary at which the dispute might continue to take place. There would then have to be a further requirement to move the figure from 15 per cent to a lower figure.

PARA.TAB: The government has responded to some of the difficulties in this area by allowing income reassessments for families who fall below the income threshold for maximum rate of additional family payment even if they do not have a 25 per cent reduction. In the light of that and the fact that, on the best surveys the government has been able to carry out, the cost would be a very significant sum of $125 million a year, the government is not prepared to accept these amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite the obvious injustice that is inherent in the current legislation—that is the phrase that should have been added by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley)—the committee has before it a matter that has been raised by Senator Woodley. It is clear that the way in which the current income test operates denies to persons who, at the particular time, on any measure ought to be able to receive family payment and yet they are denied such payment.

PARA.TAB: When one talks about universal payments and income testing, one should bear in mind that such a system has been operating in Australia for a considerable time. The family payment is really a recognition of the fact that a family with children is a more expensive operation than a family without children. It goes some way to recognising that it is unfair to tax the necessities of life in respect of a particular child.

The basis of this payment goes back many years. Previously a tax allowance was provided for families with children in respect of each child. This then turned into a tax rebate. We would not be talking about this item today if it were still a tax rebate. But in fact the rebate was cashed up into a family allowance. I agreed with that at the time when it happened in 1976. The social security shadow minister at the time also agreed—and of course at the time Labor was in opposition. The then Labor shadow minister expressed concern as to cashing up this payment into family allowance, which is now family payments. Concern was expressed that this would be eroded, and in fact that is what has happened. The position has been eroded and billions of dollars have been taken out of the purses of mothers by successive governments.

We now face a situation where, because of the income test, there is an anomaly. One could have a family suffering a substantial drop in income. This could take such a family below the income test threshold, yet the family would still remain ineligible. I do not regard that as fair. This is what amendments Nos 1, 2, and 3 of the Democrats are seeking to overcome. I would have thought that that is a reasonable proposition. I will certainly be supporting it.

These amendments seek to change the requirement that, to be eligible for the new widow allowance, a woman must have become widowed, separated or divorced after she turned 50 years of age. My amendments will simply lower that age threshold to 40 years of age. It seems unreasonable to me—I have had many representations along these lines—that a 50-year-old woman who is widowed after she turned 50 should be eligible for the allowance while one who is widowed a year earlier or even six months earlier is not.

PARA.TAB: I am moving these amendments in recognition of the difficulties faced by women who lose their partner later in life. I recognise the need to set a limit at some age level, but I believe that setting it at 50 ignores the plight of those who lost their partner whilst in their 40s.

The government, through the partner allowance, is saying that women over 40 and unemployed couples should not have to fulfil the activity test. I certainly agree with it. As in previous bills that have been brought to this place that are part of the social security package, these bills have what the Greens view as a most inappropriate usage of prison penalties. The two amendments that the Greens present are for prison penalties to be replaced with fines in the form of penalty units.

PARA.TAB: The reason we have done this is that, firstly, we believe it is not appropriate to have prison penalties within the Social Security Act. The Crimes Act provides for penalties when offences of a sufficient order involve some kind of fraud or misappropriation of money. These are clearly not applicable in this instance.

The amendments refer to two proposed sections of the bill. One is proposed section 951(6) on page 28, which says that prison penalties apply for the failure to comply with a notice requiring a person to provide the Department of Social Security a statement concerning matters relating to the benefit. The second proposed section is 408JC(6) on page 138, where there is a gender specific penalty because it relates to the widow allowance. Apparently the prison penalties there are prescribed for the same reason as in the other case—the failure to provide a statement.

We believe that exposes how ridiculous these provisions are and we urge the chamber to support these proposed amendments. There is no justification for using prison penalties in this bill. There is no justification for using the deterrence argument. It is quite obvious that people will not see this as an appropriate way of enforcing their compliance with statements relating to their benefits. We have to assume that people who are filling in these details have made a mistake. If we do not, we are assuming that they are guilty and not even allowing them a case by inserting these provisions as a deterrent.

So I urge my colleagues in the chamber to support these amendments. I will continue to address these inappropriate penalties whenever they are included in these bills until, at some point, we all see the light and refuse to do it. If any honourable senators are thinking that fines for social security misdemeanours of this kind are utterly inappropriate because the people may already be suffering, so be it. Let that be the message. If fines are inappropriate, surely prison penalties are even worse. I urge honourable senators to support my amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know it is the end of the session but usually when there are amendments it is a courtesy that those amendments are circulated outside the chamber to the various parties so that we all have time to look at them. In this case, this is the first time I have seen the amendments. I do not know whether there was any attempt to circulate them. I have seen independent senators go ape when amendments have been dropped on them without notice. I am not going ape, but I am expressing my dissatisfaction and concern that I have not had time to look at these amendments. With the disability wage supplement bill, the Greens attempted to make similar amendments and, from memory, the coalition opposed them. The amendments do the same in the context of the widow allowance.

PARA.TAB: I think I said on the earlier occasion—I do not want to be held to it—that the clause allows for a fine and/or a gaol sentence to be imposed. The argument we made then was that there was the option of either a fine and/or a gaol sentence. On that occasion, the disability wage supplement bill, we opposed the Greens' amendments. I ask that the Greens, if it is at all possible, circulate their amendments beforehand in order to give us time to consider them.

I take it—Senator Chamarette might like to give me this assurance later—that we are not talking about major fraud, which is covered under other sections of legislation and under other sections of the criminal code. TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to know the government's reasons for not acknowledging in a parenting allowance the number of children that the parents involved in the caring situation are caring for and parenting. What are the government's reasons?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that recognition of the number of children is essentially picked up through the family payment system and not through the design of the parenting allowance.

PARA.TAB: Historically, the basic family payment scheme is part of the tax transfer scheme which recognises that a family with children has a reduced ability to pay tax. TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

PARA.TAB: I ask the minister on what basis the new parenting allowance is to be income and assets tested. On what basis is it to be income tested? TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that is not right, that Senator Harradine's understanding is not in line with the government's understanding. —I think it is fairly clear and I have studied the legislation. TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine's suggestion of splitting income is not correct. The families cannot split their income. —I am sorry, they do split their income. The explanatory memorandum is quite clear on the matter and so is the legislation. The fact is that the first $61 a fortnight of the parenting allowance is tax free. That is understood. But that is a different point. The point I am raising is this: is it or is it not the fact that, for the purposes of the parenting allowance, the income of both parents is taken into account; in other words, the income test is on the couple's joint income? If, for example, one of the parents is the recipient of, say, 85 per cent of the income in that household and the other parent is the recipient of only 15 per cent of the income, the total income is divided into two.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am standing here between Senator Harradine insisting one thing and being advised and understanding that that is not the understanding of the government. Senator Harradine's saying it over and over will not change it. That is not the understanding and that is not the basis for the government's income testing of the parenting allowance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could the minister please direct the attention of the committee to the particular page of the explanatory memorandum where what she is alleging is explained? SPEECH.PARA: When calculating the rate of parenting allowance, income of both members of a couple will be taken into account.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Senator.

—What we are talking about and what page 1 of the explanatory memorandum states is a very important matter because of the logical consequences. TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know how often I can say this: no. Let me read something that might assist Senator Harradine, and this is explained further on page 43 of the explanatory memorandum. The partner's income will start to affect the allowance of the other member of the couple only when the person stops receiving an allowance altogether. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge that there are limitations in a form such as this. I will reserve my examination of this matter to perhaps an estimates committee. Perhaps the minister's department can take this on notice, as it did on a previous matter when I asked questions in this chamber relating to the home child-care allowance, including the department's legal warrant to income test that particular matter. PARA.TAB: Finally, I wish to draw attention to something that is acknowledged by the government in the second reading speech to this bill. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: A further feature of the new allowance is that low income families will have a greater degree of choice about whether one partner will stay at home and care for their children, a choice generally available up to now only to those on higher incomes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was in government then?

Particularly in the 1980s, a situation arose—because of a combination of factors, including government policy—where only well-to-do families could seriously have a choice. That is a shame. We have got to the stage now where families' incomes are such that families have to work harder and longer hours for less. That is something that we really have to look at in due course, and the sooner the better.

We would like to add that what needs to be considered is a person's capacity to negotiation, understand and comply with. It should be self-evident that many long-term unemployed people have low verbal and communications skills. This would bring into question the capacity of many to adequately negotiate an agreement. This is entirely relevant to some of the amendments that have already been spoken to by Senator Margetts. The lopsidedness of what we see before us is demonstrated by the exclusion of such considerations as a person's ability to negotiate.

PARA.TAB: I ask the chamber to remember that we are talking about young people who have completed secondary school but who have had no experience in the work force. They have not yet been able to determine what their path in the work force is, where they fit and what capacity they have to do paid work of value that can satisfy their employers. From that standpoint the young person is at a great disadvantage when facing up to a case manager with—I suggest, from some of the briefing material from the department—two weeks experience in handling the immense number of cases we are told they are capable of handling. Two weeks would be enough to overwhelm any of the individuals they are managing.

In that time, we are led to believe, these managers will be capable of dealing with some hundreds of people. From my own experience of working in this area, I know that the person who is on the side of the desk seeing different young people presenting themselves day after day rapidly learns the tricks of the trade, the negotiation skills. If we add to that a reduced capacity to succeed in verbal skills and comprehension skills, we really are talking about people who are at the rough end of the stick.

We also have to keep in mind that with the privatisation of this side of the business, with the bonuses on placement and with the heavy number to be managed, we really are putting a great deal of weight on the side of the completion of a quick, sharp, efficient negotiation period—`Here you are, sonny Jim, sign this and get out of my way.' That is the temptation. What do we have in this legislation to safeguard against that?

I understand that ESRA is trying to establish reasonable standards for case managers. But I am still concerned, especially when I look at clauses like clause 44—and we may talk about this again—that the case managers will be in a position of power and capable of railroading the unemployed into agreeing to almost anything. So it is the department's role to ensure that does not happen. While clause 39(6) requires the department to have regard to the person's needs before approving an agreement, that still does not adequately take into account whether the agreement has been properly negotiated.

I would suggest that the Democrats' amendments would require the government to take into account—a different matter entirely—the person's ability to negotiate and understand as well as the capacity to comply with this agreement. I think it is a commonsense agreement. If the person has very poor communication skills or very low comprehension skills, then the department would be alerted by this section and would have a very close look at that particular agreement. I think that is only reasonable. It does bring us to the theme that has come from Senator Margetts and me, that there needs to be more balance in the negotiation between the case manager and the managed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Bell's amendments Nos 2 and 3. There is no doubt in my mind that, if we were not dealing with younger people, most people would be properly appalled at the fact that we can expect and allow that there would be an agreement without negotiation. If, as we have seen, there will be a greater proportion of private enterprise dealing as case managers, then how do we make sure that they do not have the power of law to basically trammel over the rights and the interests of the people they are dealing with in order to make sure that they make the most profit? I am finding it harder and harder to understand how all the rhetoric is going to be matched by the outcomes here.

—The coalition will not be supporting amendments Nos 2 and 3 as put forward by Senator Bell. We believe that the particular concerns that he has talked about are covered in the rest of the bill, in the case management clauses. We will not support these two amendments.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes the amendments. We believe there is already in the bill the correct balance between the duties, responsibilities and powers of the case manager and the duties, responsibilities and rights of the job seeker. We believe that the amendments, if carried, would unbalance those powers unnecessarily and would create some problems. We will oppose the amendments.

—The coalition will be opposing this amendment. TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government does not support the amendment either. I think Senator Troeth has concisely explained why this amendment is unnecessary. We believe that the amendment would be administratively onerous in that it imposes on the case manager the requirement to gauge the merit or benefit to the community of the proposed community based or artistic activity and then balance against the other elements of the job seeker's activity agreement to somehow achieve an equitable mix of obligations and activities.

PARA.TAB: It is the government's firm view that the primary focus of any proposed activity, be it voluntary, community based or artistic work, should be its benefit to the job seeker in terms of equipping that person to effectively compete in the job market rather than some intangible benefit that the activity may provide to the community while the person continues on allowance. Again, I endorse the remarks of Senator Troeth. The government in no way undervalues the contribution of voluntary work to the community. But I think, in one sense, we are really comparing apples with pears in respect of the definition of `voluntary work' that is contained in the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I detected even in the tone of the minister's reply some of the attitude that is in the bill of a deliberate distinction between the heroic jobs market and the despised community work, that one is wonderful and the other one must not really be supported too much because it might get away from us. From my personal experience of some five years as a youth worker seeking to place people in employment, I found that the most successful precursor to employment is employment in any capacity and that those who are able to be gainfully occupied are those who are most readily employed for money at a future date.

PARA.TAB: The establishment of work patterns, responsibility, communication skills, self-esteem and a pattern of participation in the mature world all are derived from participation in voluntary work for community organisations, ranging from meals on wheels to reading stories to people in care in homes for the aged, to mowing lawns, to helping at school crossings, and the list goes on. Those who work in these areas know the immense amount of community work which is valued and valuable—both valued by the community and valuable to the giver.

I thought that we would have heard something other than the first sentence the minister came out with—that it was just a little bit onerous for the case manager. My jolly word it is onerous and there ought to be a bit of onerousness. When we get to the stage where it is just a matter of clicking through the files and being efficient, that is when we ought to be concerned. I think the rhetoric of this whole package has sucked along a few too many people. We should stop and question just what is being delivered by this great piece of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments seek to recognise the benefit of voluntary community based and artistic work and its intrinsic value. They aim to ensure that, where a person proposes self-employment in the community sector, a slightly less onerous test is applied to approval of such a proposal. For a full commercial and self-employment proposal, the secretary must be satisfied that the venture will be commercially viable within 12 months. We suggest that if the proposal has a community element it will result in some benefit to the community and is likely to be commercially viable in 12 months. I think that is reasonable.

PARA.TAB: It puts a small value, a small bias, on the job compact in favour of community based work. It is not a big one; it is a small one. In applying a less strict economic test of viability on these community based self-employment proposals, whatever we lose we will pick up in a public benefit. Again, it is continuing in the same theme. If I seem less enthusiastic about it, it is because I do not like being hit on the head too many times. I have moved these clauses, anticipating some opposition to them. I ask the government to widen the concept of what `jobs' are.

I recall what I shared with a group of representatives that came to see me today. I recall the then minister for the arts, Senator McMullan, making a proposition that fine arts graduates might be able to face a less rigorous job activity test and receive their jobsearch allowance without having to trot along to the CES with such regularity. This proposition was received with some degree of interest by the arts world knowing that budding young artists, starving in garrets somewhere—or wherever they starve—were likely to be assembling their first exhibition and unlikely to be able to interrupt themselves to comply with the activity test of the CES.

I know that proposition has not been forwarded to the stage where it is working. I ask the minister to treat this thought with some degree of seriousness because it might sound a little amusing: at the time I wondered what the difference was between such artists and, say, those people who eventually reach the big time and earn their living from being world champion surfers. We saw a golfer reach his first national title just a couple of days ago.

We regularly see our sporting competitors starving to represent the country. We even see Olympic athletes—those who are capable of earning Olympic medals—unable to satisfy CES job tests. Therefore, they are unable to receive this allowance from the community but are delivering to us huge benefits and are being no less professional than any other job seeker. I will name one. For many years, the Tasmanian champion weightlifter, Ron Laycock—I am sure you, Mr Temporary Chairman, recognise the name—was unsuccessful in obtaining continued employment in his home town of Campbelltown because it was not the metropolis which could provide the part-time work which would suit his training schedule. Yet, that person was representing Australia with great distinction.

Our schemes, legislation and tests did not cater for such a person. We have hundreds of such people throughout Australia—people whom we should not be defining as unemployed, useless or unacceptable to the community. As far as this legislation is concerned, we do not take into account their many and varied activities which are, in themselves, intrinsically valuable and which provide a great deal of benefit to the community.

I could go on and list the many occupations which require a degree of dedication, practice and community input before success is finally achieved and which are not recognised either as work or as a legitimate outcome of this agreement. I have touched on a couple. These amendments give the freedom for those negotiating these agreements—and I say `negotiating' in huge inverted commas, because I do not think it is negotiating—to apply a little more flexibility so that some of the things that I spoke of could be taken into account. If they are not, my comments about the previous inflexibility apply.
