TALK.START.PARA: —Today in Sydney the winner of the Doug Moran National Portrait Prize was announced. I pay tribute not only to the artist, Josonia Palaitis, who is now $100,000 richer, but perhaps more importantly to the prize itself. The prize was initiated in 1988. It is a biannual prize initiated first as part of the bicentenary celebrations of that year. Since its inauguration it has had a major impact on the art world.

PARA.TAB: The prize was introduced, it is fair to say, at a time when portraiture, particularly in Australia, was languishing; when some of the major portrait prizes were considered by many to have gone somewhat off the rails. There was, for example, some dissatisfaction with some of the judging systems used—there was certainly some controversy—and it was felt that the winners were awarded on the basis of being fashionable and trendy rather than necessarily of the very best quality.

Since the prize was inaugurated in 1988 there has indeed been a noticeable change, which might be described as moving back towards mainline portraiture. The standard certainly has improved and, indeed, the importance of this particular prize has increased manyfold since its introduction. I think this is a reflection in many ways on the foresight of Doug and Greta Moran, who are the founders of the prize. I am sure that Doug will forgive me if I say that, although both of these two fine people have an interest in arts, Greta is the one who has the greater talent. She is about to open her own exhibition in the Parker Galleries in a day or two, she is an exhibiting member of the Royal Arts Society of New South Wales and is highly regarded and, indeed, has truly exceptional talents.

The prize itself was really a family enterprise. It was a family working together that brought the prize into reality. It is reputedly the richest prize for portraiture in the world with the first prize being $100,000 and $1,000 going to each of the 30 finalists.

The popularity was indicated by the fact that this year there were almost 500 entries. Indeed, the overall standard was amazingly high. I viewed the second 30—those who did not achieve a final—and the standard in those 30 was incredibly high as well. Part of the attraction of the prize has been that the judging has been beyond criticism. It has been completely impartial. The selection of the 30 finalists this year, for example, was undertaken by two famous Australian art world characters: John MacPhee, who is the curator of the National Gallery of Victoria; and Ron Radford, who is the director of the Art Gallery of South Australia. These men are two of the most respected members of the Australian art community.

But the actual judges of the ultimate winner are a list of who's who from the art world worldwide. They include people such as Alan Fern, who is a director of the National Portrait Gallery in the Smithsonian Institute in Washington; Michael Noakes, a renowned portrait painter of the royal family in the UK; Professor Albinovich, the Lenin prize winner from the former USSR; Professor Bruno Foucart from the Sorbonne; and the last prize was judged by Felipe Lombard, who is a director of the world famous Prado museum in Madrid.

This year the judge was Professor Nicola Spinosa, a very famous curator of art from Naples. One of the leading judges is the director of the Capo di Monte Gallery and is also the minister for art and culture in Naples. This impartiality in judging alone sets the prize apart. The fact that the prize also tours to a number of areas in New South Wales for almost two years creates enormous interest not only in the major capital cities but in many of the regional centres which it visits. It captures the imagination of artists from both professional and amateur ranks.

Doug and Greta and their family should be given great credit for making such a major impact on the art world. I think we should all be grateful for the impact this has made upon the standard of portraiture in Australia. It is a legacy to future generations. It does, of course, leave behind a representation of the changing face of Australia over the last six years but obviously in future years a longer term legacy.

Doug and Greta were also proponents of a national portrait gallery. This has now eventuated, perhaps not in the form which they envisaged but certainly their support was part of the whole process. The home of the art prize is the gallery in Murwillumbah, which Greta and Doug Moran and their family are in the process of reorganising, with the help of a former member of this parliament, Doug Anthony, who, as I understand it, donated the land where the new gallery will be built.

This year the winner of the prize, who follows in a distinguished line of previous winners, has painted a portrait of John Mills. John Mills is a well-known Australian illustrator who died at the end of 1993 at the age of 86. The portrait was painted by his daughter Josonia Palaitis, who had her training in Sydney. She studied at the national art school. She was awarded a diploma of art in 1972 and, subsequently, a degree of art at the Sydney Art Institute. She has painted many portraits of famous people, including a member of this parliament, John Howard; John Dowd from the state parliament; Justice Michael Kirby; musicians Adrian Dangerfield and James Morrison; and one of the members of the press gallery in this place, Paul Lyneham.

The portrait is indeed a stunning work. I saw this when the portraits were being exhibited at the Old Parliament House a few weeks ago. It gives an insight into John Mills. Let me say simply that, although I never met John Mills, because of this portrait, I feel I know him. I feel that I have almost seen within his soul, and surely that is one of the tests of a great portrait. I offer my congratulations to Josonia, and I especially commend the whole of the Moran family for their hard work and devotion to this great enterprise. It is one which has enriched the art world—which has enriched the portrait art world, in particular—and which has benefited the whole of the Australian community around this great country of ours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I wish to bring to the attention of the Senate a book that was launched last week entitled Never Forget Australia, its French title being—the Senate will have to excuse my pronunciation—N'oublions jamais l'Australie. The book was launched by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Con Sciacca, last week in Melbourne. It received some appropriate press coverage. At the launch were three old diggers: a Mr Brain, Mr Jim Baddeley and Claude Phillips. They were guests at the Melbourne town hall for the launch of the book. Many distinguished Australians were at the launch.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of my making a few brief remarks about the book is that, in this period when Australians are becoming more and more conscious about history, it makes a special contribution to a greater understanding of Australian history, particularly as it relates to those terrible and tragic events of the First World War. The honorary publisher of the book is a Mr Allan Blankfield. He writes:

SPEECH.PARA: The Regimental Council of the Royal Victoria Regiment was determined to send a pilgrimage party to France, to commemorate, on Anzac Day this year 1993, the 75th Anniversary of the decisive Australian victory of the Battle of Villers-Bretonneux.
He goes on to say:

Two 94 year old `Digger' veterans, thirty-four reservist soldiers and thirty-four other dedicated Australians participated in this self-funded trip to England and France, to witness the presentation of new Colours to the Royal Regiment of Fusiliers, by His Royal Highness the Duke of Kent and to participate in the French commemorative celebrations.

One of the major contributors to the book was Mr Robin Corfield, who not only painstakingly researched and wrote most of the military history but also assisted in the presentation and coordination of this book. In one of the contributions that he makes he writes about those terrible events:

Coming such a short time after Federation and the establishment of the Commonwealth of Australia, this conflict marked the new nation deeply and permanently. Of the 330,000 Australians who volunteered and went abroad some 60,000 never returned. Of these 46,000 were lost in France and Flanders. Less than 30,000 of these have marked graves, the rest are names on the Memorials to the Missing. This was a loss that robbed Australia of more than she could afford.
Some 10,000 copies of the book have been printed and will be distributed to schools, particularly in Victoria, and to schools and other institutions in the Somme region of France.

PARA.TAB: One side of the book's pages is in English; the other side has a French translation. It is a wonderfully presented book. Not only does it convey an excellent feeling of the history of that period, but it also conveys very many interesting anecdotes about the soldiers, from the private to the general, who fought in that conflict and provides many fascinating facts about the battles that were fought, the uniforms that were worn and, perhaps in some ways, the private feelings of many of those soldiers.

The text of the book is replete with wonderful photos, both tragic and heroic. It contains scenes and plans of the battles and, as I said, contains many quite fascinating facts about those events. One matter which came to my attention was the wonderful postcards that were sent home by the diggers of the First World War. It is interesting that on a number of those postcards the Australian flag was shown being very proudly waved.

It occurred to me as I read through this book how little I knew about those events. I have always taken an interest in the history of this country but, if I reflect on the education that I received in my secondary schooling, I think very little was taught in schools in the 1960s about these events. I hope that that is not the case today. This sort of book will provide young students in our educational institutions, and perhaps many of the students of my period who went through schools in the 1950s and 1960s, with a better feeling for the history of this nation.

Mr President, I commend this book to you and to honourable senators. I hope that the print run in the future will be more than 10,000 and that it will be possible for copies of this book to be distributed far and wide throughout this country. Because of the French theme in the book and the fact that much of the text is also translated into French, hopefully the book will be widely distributed in that country and, again, lead to closer contacts and understanding between Australia and France, particularly in that region of France where so many Australian soldiers served.

It is with pleasure that I bring this book to the attention of the Senate. I hope that many of my colleagues will have time to read it. I want to conclude by recalling one of the many fascinating anecdotes which appear in the book and quote an interesting story from Major General Elliott on the famous Australian slouch hat. He states:

SPEECH.PARA: In this war, in the beginning we were prepared to acquiesce silently in certain assumptions that were made as to our want of discipline and training. We even acquiesced again silently—though with grief—to the order that we should on the embarkation to Gallipoli discard our Australian hats in favour of the round caps of the British Infantry, for it was said "the Turks will know from your hats that you are irregular Australian Troops, and will therefore fight harder than if they thought they were confronted by the men of the British army."

We lived to hear it seriously proposed by a British officer, high on the general staff that, "Australian hats should be issued to a large proportion of the British army in France, so that the enemy might be stricken by the thought that they had Australian troops along a large portion of his front."

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 20 September 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the issues raised by the Auditor-General following the report on the Australian Trade Commission's Export Market Development Grants Scheme:
(1) What evidence is there that the Export Market Development Grants Scheme is overcoming export barriers and that exports are increasing.
(2) What steps will be taken to make the program more accountable to the Parliament, and what measures of performance will be used.
(3) What evidence is there to suggest that the confidence of exporters and applicants would be undermined as a result of an increase in accountability to the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) In addition to the Auditor-General's review, the EMDG Scheme has also recently been subject to a thorough evaluation of its effectiveness. The result of this evaluation was the report `Helping to Meet the Export Challenge' which was released on 27 July 1994. A copy has been sent to Senator Knowles.

This report is perhaps the most extensive evaluation of the EMDG Scheme to date and sets new standards in demonstrating the effectiveness of Government programs. Much of the research was undertaken by independent consultants from the Economic Studies and Strategies Unit of Price Waterhouse, and by Professor Bewley, Head of the School of Economics and Professor of Econometrics at the University of New South Wales. Professor Bewley demonstrated, beyond doubt, the additional results this scheme is achieving in encouraging and realising exports.

The research concluded, among other things, that the EMDG Scheme has directly encouraged firms to increase their spending on export marketing promotion in anticipation of receipt of a grant, resulting in more exports. In the case of mature exporters, the EMDG Scheme has generated increased exports in the order of 15-25 times the value of these marketing expenditures.

There is an increasing number of firms claiming under the EMDG Scheme. In the 1991/92 claim year 2,473 exporters who claimed under the program generated exports of $3.6 billion. The following year, 1992/93, 3,251 claimants had export sales of $5.2 billion. It is estimated that around 3,700 exporters will lodge claims for expenditure incurred last financial year.

(2) Austrade has largely agreed with the view expressed by the Auditor-General that improvements could be made to the performance expectations and measures for the EMDG Scheme. Austrade and the ANAO note that the Scheme has many interest groups with varying expectations of its purpose and performance. Clearly these groups, and the Scheme, would benefit from greater focus of the performance measures.

The overall performance of the Scheme is addressed comprehensively by the Evaluation mentioned above by Price Waterhouse and Professor Ron Bewley. Austrade advises that it anticipates the performance measures used in this report will continue to be publicly reported periodically. The ANAO did not have time to fully consider this report.

Improvements in other management areas are currently being implemented. However, given the number and scope of recommendations made by the Auditor-General concerning data collection and suggested performance indicators, Austrade indicated in its responses to the ANAO recommendations that it would employ an expert consultant in this field to assist in the development of key performance indicators. This process is currently under way and will be complete in February or March 1995.

(3) Austrade regards accountability to Parliament as fundamental to its operation and considers that this process raises the confidence of the business sector generally in the Scheme. As Austrade pointed out in the Auditor-General's report, the EMDG Scheme has been the subject of twelve reviews and reports in the last ten years, all of which are public documents. Austrade's experience is that individual exporters regard each examination of EMDG as reducing the certainty of the Scheme and consequently affects their confidence to increase export marketing and promotional activity.

Austrade is concerned to ensure that it effectively meets Parliament's need for information but that major evaluation and review is carried out at reasonable intervals. This will ensure that potential claimants can confidently plan additional export promotion activity on the expectation of receiving assistance.

Austrade operates under strict principles of commercial confidentiality which are regulated by Section 94 of the Australian Trade Commission Act 1985. Under that section, Austrade is barred from releasing information held on individual claimants' other than their name and the amount of the grant paid.

Austrade is concerned that the process of reporting to Parliament not result in the release of either commercial-in-confidence information on claimants which would contravene this section or information that may jeopardise individual claimants' entitlements to EMDG assistance.

Austrade expects that a sensible approach to Parliamentary reporting with realistic expectations from stakeholders and a commitment to the commercial integrity of the Scheme will retain the confidence of the Parliament, exporters and potential applicants to the Scheme.
